Our stay here was good.Upon arrival staff were very helpful and pleasant.We stayed on a high floor at the rear.This was quiet, and the room was very clean with a comfy king size bed.The bathroom was spotless, and the shower had a pulsate setting that I like.The room wasn't huge, but it wasn't small either.There was room to walk around and a wardrobe to hang clothes.Also, there is a small refrigerator.Here's a tip ..The A/C is also a heater (if you are cold) that takes a few minutes to blow warm air(maybe 10 minutes).Breakfast on the lobby level includes waffles and cerial choices also muffins and coffee.We were quite satisfied with our stay.

We travelled to New York in May / June in 2012 , there were 6 of us in total, 2 couples and two single women. This accommodation provided us with two rooms, one for one couple and two adjoining rooms for the other couple and the two singles I.e. separate room for couple and also for the two single women as the adjoining room had two double beds. The hotel was in a great location , close to station etc. breakfast was included . Hotel was having a face lift when we were there and is old but so are most things in New York. We would definitely stay there again.

Stayed at the 25th street Comfort inn where they up graded there rooms in 2012 and had a wonderful stay. The room were ok size however with all new funiture and bedding I was very pleased with the hotel. They offer a very good cont breakfast along with the room rate. The location is excellent if you need to visit lower Manhattan. My next trip to the city I will be staying at the Comfort Chelsa on 25th stree.

This hotel is in a fantastic location but it's downhill from there. The rooms are less than basic and very small. The beds were comfortable but the rooms are at best grubby and in dire need of a good clean. The entire hotel would benefit from a revamp and a deep clean. The continental breakfast is poor and there are only paper plates, cups and plastic cutlery. Tea and coffee is available 24 hours a day. Some of the staff are pleasant and others miserable / rude. Luckily I was only there for 3 nights and out most of the time so I only had to sleep there. There is a strange smell in the hotel and if u manage to take a peek into the staff only areas these are deplorable! As I've said the hotel is in a great location, 20 minutes walk to Times square and not far from The Empire State building and there is a subway station just around the corner. If you want a great location and don't mind the smell etc then this hotel is ok.

I led a recent School trip which stayed here last week. Overall I thought it was a great hotel for our three night stay. Depending on your experience of New York, you could be disappointed with the room size, but let's face it, if you're going for the hotel then you've missed the point! The reception staff were helpful but we never saw the same person twice. The lifts are quite slow and not too big so be prepared to wait. Our room was clean and well prepared, the bathroom was cramped but functional. The breakfast is awesome with loads of hot and cold options, way better than the continental we were exoecting. The metro at W25th street, gives great access up and downtown making it an ideal location for a base. Ultimately I would go back without hesitation.

Ok I saw some of the other reviews and I was nervous. However, this hotel was perfect for what we needed. Some rooms are set to the back of the building so it was very quiet. Old small elevators but not a problem. Friendly and quick check in and the rooms were very clean. I would stay here again for a great price in NY and it's right by the park in Flatiron District.

I made a reservation for this hotel and received the worst customer service in return. My cancellation deadline on the e-mail that received directly from the hotel said "If you need to change or cancel this reservation, you may do so up until Sunday, January 27, 2013, before 4pm local hotel time. The reservation cannot be cancelled through email." I called on January 27th, 1:30 p.m. and they refused to honor it. I was called a liar and someone cheap who doesn't want to pay. The lowest attitude I ever got as a consumer. I am beyond disappointed for this behavior and will make sure that I will never use this brand myself. Be aware of this rude behavior regarding the hotels' perception of customer service.
user_name:
naz a
New York City, New York

review_body: It is a great hotel if you don't mind the small size. Internet is available and free continental breakfast that is pretty decent. Best part is it's affordable for New York prices. The elevator is older, but we didn't have any issues.

The hotel is located in a convenient location of Chelsea. I am used to room size in New Mexico so this was a tiny room, but that's how it is in NYC, so that's not a negative but something to keep in mind and be prepared for.First the good...We had a room with two single beds and it was very clean, especially the bathroom. The towel and linen quality was excellent. The room design was nifty, considering the tight space. They wear full house so we could only get a smoking room, however, the room had no smoking smell at all which was a huge relief for us. The breakfast was large for NYC and well kept. They keep the breakfast replenished constantly and an African American gentleman who was working there was the hardest working guy I saw in manhattan on this trip! He did not waste a nano second and accommodated every request from demanding guests, especially those European group, who seem to eat a lot!!! Check in and check out was smooth...The tv channels were so so...the tv was wide screen but the reception was analog and poor. I don't get the point, they invest in a wide screen tv, why skimp on the content? Give less channels but provide at least the networks in hi-def! It was not fun to watch playoff game in analog...The parking across the street is a rip off...go north on 6th avenue and make left (west) on 31st street, six blocks away...there is cheaper parking there. Two blocks south, broadway and 23rd, there is a great place called Eatly, they have great espresso, gelato and all fancy stuff. Overall, not a bad deal for $119 per night in Chelsea ....will return!

This is not the nicest place, but it does offer quite a bit for the low price. The location is perfect. they offer free internet and a morning continental breakfast that is not that bad. The room was small, but very clean and well appointed. Again, for the price you could do much worse in New York. I was perfectly satisfied.

An Excellent price for NYC. Lobby and entrance were unremarkable. But this isn't the Ritz and it doesn't pretend to be. One tiny elevator, which could be a long wait for some, but we didn't experience any problems with that. Stayed in a king room on the fifth floor facing 25th Street. I personally wasn't bothered by street noise. The room has it's own heating/air conditioning unit, and with the heat/fan on, sleeping was fine. The room was tight, but that's the norm in New York. Bathroom was very tiny, but clean. You had to step up a few inches to enter it, a little treacherous at night. Free internet worked fine and t.v. was a flat screen with a limited number of channels. In spite of scaffolding on front of the building, we had a nice view of a pretty church across the street and a partial view of the Empire State Building! Cool! My husband made use of the free breakfast and said it was fine. Concierge will store your bags in a locked room. If you do this after checking out, there's a $1 fee per bag. No biggie. Convenient to subway/public transportation. Eataly is right around the corner. Easy walk to Union Square (Christmas Market is awesome there!)...Overall, an older (slightly dated) hotel, but clean and in a safe convenient location. Would stay there again.

A block from beautiful Madison Square, Broadway and the N Line train means Chinatown, Times Square and Central Park are all within 15 minutes without changing trains... N Line also goes direct to Coney Island). A much better price than other comparable hotels we stayed at in recent years (e.g., Four Points Soho). Our room was small to be sure, but king size bed was very comfortable, lcd tv 42", room and bath were both spotless, we had a view of the Empire State Bldg, and the furniture and wallpaper seemed new. There are more than a few excellent restaurants within short walking distance, and Madison Square Park at night is wonderful. 15 minutes or less walk to Empire State Building or Times Square, straight up Broadway so you can window-shop on your way, passing Manhattan Mall, Macy's and Lord and Taylor, as well as countless discount souvenier shops. One block to Eataly, a great Italian food court for lunch. About ten blocks to Penn Station. Service was friendly and the free breakfast, while nothing special, was bountiful, offering a lot of variety. Concierge is weak, looking for the upsell instead of offering insider tips, but the front desk personnel were all great. Considering the price and location, I want to give this place five stars but our room was too small and concierge not helpful even compared to my own knowledge just from reading TripAdvisor forum and Fodor's ahead of time.

suppose to be a christmas vacation for my children and they put us in a room with twin beds one was higher than the other and they heat our room with a window air conditianer,the concier could not give me info on different place i wanted to go but the black guy in the breakfast room help me out alot

It always amazes me how different the professional pictures look than my experience in the hotel itself. I did not think it was a good hotel to stay in and I would not stay here again. The room and the bathroom were very small. The staff was not particularly friendly. It was a hotel that young backpackers might stay in. If you are looking for comfort or for an extended stay, I would not stay here. If you have a car, you will have to walk 2 blocks to the garage to park it yourself.

I had to spend a night in Manhattan for business purposes and was thrilled to find this little gem! Althought it was $299 for the night, I realize that is quite reasonable for Manhattan. While it is an older building, the room was clearly well-cared for ... and absolutely huge for NYC (with a sitting couch, flat screen tv, desk, and adequate bathroom). I was quite impressed and would not hesitate to stay there again should I be in the neighborhood.

I stayed here for 4 nights and it was a really nice stay,the location is excellent and the rooms were tidy and the bathroom was a decent size. The service was good and also the breakfast was nice! Nothing to complain about! Would recommend it to anyone who wants to go to new york for a few days as the price is very resonable!

I stayed at this hotel last week for 5 nights, the rooms are not great and the bathroom is small, however it is a good hotel to stay at for a couple of nights as it is cheap and is in a good locations, for example, walking distance to many attractions in NYC, if you are looking for a cheap couple of days in NYC this is a good hotel to stay at.

The rooms are very basic and very small. To think some of the rooms can hold 4 or 6 people is mad. The bathroom is really, really small as well, plus the toilets have a tendency to clog up very easily. There is also no view from any of the rooms, apart from a few on the top floor. However, there are a few plus points to this hotel. The rooms have a safe, which is handy. Also, it's situated in a good location- near a subway station and many landmarks. I stayed here during hurricane Sandy, and all the power and water went. This was ok for someone on the 5th floor, but any more than that, and it was hard work up and down the stairs! The hotel managed the situation very well, but I moved to another hotel due to there being no water for several days.

Had a 1 night stay, and to be honest probably one night is enough. We booked the room as it has the option of a family room which is two connecting rooms, one with a queen size bed and the other with 2 doubles. We had 2 adults and 2 kids staying. The rooms are small but enough room for sleeping there. The bathroom was also small and the door had to fully open to get in and out of it. This room has the appearance of being a larger room that has been converted a while ago to accomodate a family. The whole decor of the hotel is very worn and aged. The hotel was quite noisy, you could hear everyone walking in the corridor outside the room and if one of the adjacent room doors shut it sounded like someone was knocking on our room door. There was also ALOT of noise most of the night from the streets below, we were on the 10th floor but it sounded like a construction site most of the night, alot of trucks and banging going on. As the rooms have individual air conditioners, it's almost like you have an open window all night so the noise is amplified. For a one night stay it was fine, but I wouldn't want to stay for an extended period of time.

Yes it's cheap. But Holiday Inn is also cheap and is far better both in terms of accommodation and service.My room stank of mildew, had a dodgy looking electric socket that was hanging from the wall and a dubious stain on the bedspread. The wall in the bathroom was smeared with something that looked like dried mucous near the loo roll holder. If I could have left I would have (long story, but I couldn't).Final straw was the staff's complete indifference to a request to check out late (and a willingness to pay for the privilege) since my trans Atlantic flight didn't leave until 7pm. I understand if it's just not possible, but the dismissive attitude was annoying after such a disappointing stay.

I go to New York every year. The last few years I have stayed at this place on 25th street. It's right in lthe Flatiron building area. So much to see and do in the area. It is reasonably priced considering the NY hotel rates. The rooms are clean and nicely setup. Two great improvements are the expanded breakfast area and WiFi in every room. The staff is very helpful and very friendly. The service was excellent. I wil stay here again next trip to NY.

Ok... bad hotel, that's for sure but :Pros :- location : amazing ! nothing to say, now I understand why some 3 or even 4 stars hotels located on the upper-west side are cheaper. - free wifi (yay!!)- beds are extremely confortableCons :- room size : you are going to sleep in a shoe box. Take note of that.- bathroom : small. old. shower is awful. hot water is not even provided on a regular basis. - Staff : worst staff in NYC. Not even a smile, nothing. execrable.- Breakfast : worst breakfast in NYC. Do not go there, it's disgusting and the atmosphere is terrible.- noise : it's a noisy hotel, there are people screaming around all the time, doors & windows are old and noisy, etc.- i think that's enough.Enjoy the location ! ;)

We had an excellent stay, the staff was very friendly and helpful. The bed was comfortable. The location is fantastic, we walked from Penn Station to the hotel and many other things in the area. The subway takes you anywhere, we even got to Coney Island, an unexpected surprise. The biggest surprise was the adjacent Chinese Restaurant. We had avoided it thinking it was "just too convenient to be good". We were pleasantly surprised on the evening we were just too tired to do anything else. It was the best Chinese we ever had. Back to the room, we were happy that the window would open enough for fresh air, and also appreciated that the room didn't smell of that cleaner/spray stuff that we all hate.

Was in New York on business for two days, where my activities were centred in the Chelsea area, so I was pleased to find this hotel just minutes away from where I had to be. Although the hotel is an older building, my room had obviously been renewed and was small but very pleasant. I had a very comfortable king-size bed, plus a desk, desk-chair, comfortable chair for reading, flat-screen television, free wi-fi, air conditioner, and the best lighting I have ever had in a hotel. The bathroom was small but clean. The room looked out into a courtyard and was very quiet. A free breakfast was provided in a bright and clean breakfast room and was billed as a "continental breakfast", although it included both hard-boiled and scrambled eggs, bacon, and waffles, as well as the standard dry cereal, toast, muffins, etc. The only problem, and a very minor one, was the slowness of the elevators. Staff was nice and helpful. I'd stay again if I had business in the are.

In a big city you expect an overpriced, small basic room. Well, not quite at this Comfort Inn in Chelsea. The 'inn' part of the name might be a little misleading as it was a proper hotel an on superb location within walking distance of all the sights in Manhattan.We loved it!If I would have to mention a negative, it would be the lifts - they are a bit on the slow side. Then again, who really cares about lift speeds? The hotel has no dining or drinking facilities, but I can recommend the Chinese next door as well as the bar/restaurant called The Hog Pit in the next street.We loved every bit of our stay! Thank you, Comfort Inn!

Do not stay here if you are looking for a luxury hotel experience. It feels more like a European Hotel, a bit tired and worn. BUT, if you are looking for clean rooms, helpful and friendly staff (handyman came within 5 mins to sort out a minor plumbng problem at 6.30am), great location and breakfast too - this is the place for you. We are a family of 4 had had a large room with 2 double beds and a sofa, all a bit dull but clean. The room had no view and the aircondition was a bit noisy, but we didn't come to New York to spend time in our hotel room looking out a window! The rate was 50% of most others we looked at.The surrounding area has a great atmosphere, feels like the "real" New York rather than the tourist trap of Times Square or the soulless shopping or business districts. A selection of subway routes within one or two blocks and the PATH train to Hoboken just a short walk away too. Great fun watching all the dog walkers in the park while munching on a famous Shake Shack burger.

This is an older hotel showing signs of its age. The elevators were extremely slow and the stairwells very low and narrow. The rooms were older and out dated but relatively clean for the age. The hotel was a great value with a good location. Close to the subway. Would recommend for travelers looking for a great value with a good location. Not a sleek modern room or hotel but a clean reasonable price play to stay.

Two of us travelled to this hotel from Canada from Sept 9-13th 2012 in order for my partner to read names at the 9/11 memorial. The only thing we had done was read some reviews about this hotel and knew very little else about the area so were quite nervous about staying here as some of the reviews weren't too "upbeat". We were absolutely THRILLED with what we found.Yes, it's a small hotel. Yes the rooms are small. What do you expect for under $300.00 a night in downtown Manhattan? Yes, there is a bit of construction (there is a light at the end though...they are almost done). Our room was spotless, the halways small but spotless, the lobby the same, as was the breakfast room which can sit up to 35 people at a time (I counted chairs because several complained it was so small.) Breakfast was typical Comfort Inn---all you need to start your day. Coffee, toast scrambled eggs, bagels, cereal, waffles, fruit, yogurt etc. If you want Eggs Benedict, stay at a Four Seasons.We can't thank the staff enough for being as outgoing as they were. The concierge(s) helped us on several occasions, the front desk staff couldn't have been more helpful if they tried, and the info they had on the area/restraunts etc was superb!We had a king bed with two end tables, a desk, wardrobe, bar fridge, coffee maker, 42 inch flat screen, in room free wifi, and fresh towels/coffee daily. Air conditioning was just fine too. Yes, the bathroom was small, but just how much time do you need to spend in a bathroom? It's not like you are sleeping in there! The view looked at another building, but if we'd wanted a "view" we would have stayed on Central Park. We could walk EVERYWHERE in a very short period of time. And we walked from the World Trade Centre memorial back in about 45 minutes. Madison Square Park is 1 minute around the corner, "Eatily" is 3 minutes away, subway the same...what more do you need?We are definitely happy about this hotel, it's location, the staff, cleanliness---everything that we encountered. And we have travelled a great deal all over the US, Canada, Carribean. Would DEFINITELY stay here again...could've stayed at a high-end hotel but why when we were just there to sleep? Don't hesitate to book into this gem of a place.

My boyfriend and I stopped over in New York City for a couple days on our way to Montreal, Canada. We were taking an early morning train to Montreal so we wanted to stay at a reasonably priced nice hotel in walking distance from Penn Station. Staying at the Comfort Inn Chelsea exceeded our needs and helped make this leg of our trip a really nice experience.Check-in went quickly and smoothly; staff was very friendly. We were pleased with our king room, it was a little small as our bed dominated the room but the room was clean and in good condition. We thought it had been recently renovated as everything seemed newer (i.e., paint, wallpaper, etc.) The bathroom was also clean and in good condition, though also a little on the small side. My only complaint was there wasn't much space to put anything in the tub area, i.e. full size shampoo, conditioner, etc. The refrigerator worked well as did the nice sized flat screen tv. The bed was huge and very comfy; we both slept very well and the room was very quiet despite the building work and renovations being done. We had no problems with wi-fi, which was fortunate since you have to pay by the minute to use the internet in the hotel business center. The A/C worked really well too.Location was great; I felt it was a very safe neighborhood and centrally located to the attractions we wanted to visit. The concierge was friendly and helpful in directing us as well. Getting to the subway was an easy walk and there were a lot of close by places to eat and buy stuff that we needed unexpectedly. Breakfast was pleasant; there was a nicely appointed dining area that was large and well maintained. There was an array of hot and cold items that was plentiful, plus Belgian wafflemakers were available. We had a very early start to go take the train at Penn Station but breakfast was ready and waiting! Check-out went smoothy as well.I would definitely be willing to stay here again the next time I'm in NYC; the reasonable prices, great location, amenities and proximity to Penn Station make it a great value!

We (2 fam. travelling with teenagers) had a return visit to NYC and the Comfort Inn. Travelling with 2 teens we needed 2 rooms or app. and therefore chose the Comfort Inn again. You get a good deal when booking the 2 room app. with 1 king and 2 queens. Leaves you enough space...and reasonably prized - esp. if you book early - for NY. Though we did have just one bathroom, but its NY, small but clean, so no complains...Rooms were well kept, in good condition. Breakfast was plenty and quite good. Best is the location just around the corner from Flat Iron Building. And of course in Chelsea...just love this quarter...If travelling again with 4 p/fam. I would def. choose this hotel again...the price-offer is just unbeatable then......to mention sleeping...very quiet although with the building-work outside (they usually do not work in the night...hah...)...and the beds were really fantastic...no complaints...Reg. the website fotos: the BAR does not exist...it's used as breakfast room...

My son and I stay in NYC every few months. This is the first time we've stayed at this Comfort Inn - we usually stay at another hotel in Chelsea. We stayed from August 31-Sept. 2. Rates were lower on Friday night but went up for the weekend. The Comfort Inn is a bit less expensive than our usual hotel, but it is also not at the level of some of the other area hotels. Our room with two twin beds wasn't tiny but was small, as was the bathroom. It was adequate - a bit worn and dated, and smelled musty until we ran the air conditioner. Walls are thin so we could hear noises around us as well as street noise. The hotel is undergoing a facelift, so the stairwell nearby us was dusty, and there was plaster on the rugs. There are two elevators, both of which are slow. The building itself is narrow but has a certain charm. The staff can be a bit disorganized. They had listed our reservation under my husband's first name, though he had booked it in both his and my name, so they couldn't find the reservation without the confirmation number. A man registering next to us had booked a room with a roll-away only to be informed that the roll-away might not fit in his room and that he might need to book an additional room. Breakfast is mediocre, though there are hard boiled eggs. On the plus side, the hotel is very well located between Greenwich Village and Times Square so it's possible to walk almost anywhere.

Stayed here for a friend's bachelorette party. It was centerally located to everything we wanted to do. The breakfast was suprisiling good and included bacon and hot eggs. The room we had was tiny but we werent expecting too much in the middle of manhatten. The hotel was clean and had all the ameneties we needed. The staff was kind enough to let us leave our luggage until we could check in as we arrived very early. They even refrigerated our leftovers. Concierge was very helpful. Would definetly stay again if I am lucky enought to get back to New York.
user_name:
Cassandra T
Bellingham, Washington, United States

review_body: My husband and I stayed there from August 4-6 and were pleasantly surprised. Although the hotel doesn't look that great from the outside, the room was well equipped with kingsize bed and larger than we expected. It was very clean and the bed quite comfortable with ample pillows. It was an extremely hot weekend so the aircon was an absolute necessity. It worked like a charm and was reasonably quiet. Internet was included and worked flawlessly. The flat screen TV had a good selection of channels including HBO lineup. Bathroom was clean; amenities were plentiful. Shower pressure decent. Soundproofing was also very good. Two elevators helped transport us up to our 10th floor rooom. Staff was helpful especially the "doorman" who helped us navigate into a tight parking spot right across the street, saving us the expense of a private parking lot. The morning complementary breakfast was a big hit with a nice variety of hot and cold options. Newspapers also complementary. In addition, the location is great if you like Chelsea. Fun shopping and restaurants galore. Macy's is also within walking distance and subways nearby. All in all a very good experience at the Comfort Inn. It exceeded my expectations for a 2 star property. Would certainly consider staying there in the future.

My father and I stayed here for a couple nights from July 29-31, 2012. For older building the entire property immaculately clean. I found the shower to slippery and was concerned my father would slip and get injured. I mentioned my concern to the manager on our first morning there. When we returned to the room in the afternoon there was shower mat in tub. Everyone we encountered was extremely helpful, courteous and was able to help us or if not directed to someone who could help. I highly recommend this hotel and would stay here again on my next visit. It's located in a great area with many restaurant choices. We enjoyed "Eataly" a couple blocks south of the hotel. Thank you for helping to make my visit to NYC great!

Not overly huge rooms but typically new York apparently. Very clean and neat, good service and great to be able to start the day with a good continental breakfast including a great DYI waffle machine...subway station just minutes away with one station to times square and in a quiet street. We were very pleased.

We stayed there from Monday, July 9- Sunday, July 15. We were in town for a fashion show and were usually carrying a lot of stuff in and out. Not once did the concierge get up from watching movies on his phone to assist us with the bags or getting a cab or anything. Glued to his phone. We also had to keep calling the front desk to get our room cleaned. On 2 separate days we were unable to get room cleaned because they were gone for the day. The front desk personnel were constantly on Facebook and you-tube so when you needed something you had to say "Excuse me" just to get them to acknowledge you. We will never stay there again.

Spent 4 nights here last week with my husband and our three young adult children (ages 16, 18, 20). We had a family suite which had a room with 2 double beds and a big flat screen TV and another room with a king bed and another big flat screen TV. The bathroom was small - but served its purpose just fine! The hotel provides a complementary breakfast which is great for a family like ours. Rooms were clean and nicely furnished. Nothing extravagant - but that's not what we paid for either. All in all - we'd certainly use this hotel again. The location was great; close to the subway and mid-way between downtown and uptown Manhattan. Alot of families much like ours here.

I travel to nyc every two weeks and have stayed in this hotel more times than I care to remember. I want to like this hotel because it is so close to my office and the building looks like it had a proud owner in the past, but now...ugh!I always come out of this place more tired than when I entered, so be warned if you are in the city for business that doesnt revolve around you being in a sleep apnea study.The best part of the free breakfast is the hard-boiled egg that comes pre-peeled in a bag. Doesnt that sound amazing!?!
Very convenient location within walking distance of all attractions.

The hotel has a great location- the iconic Flatiron Building and the very chic Madison Square Garden Park are literally around the corner, Time Square is about a 20 minutes walk and the Empire State Building is less than 10 minutes away on foot. The Hotel is situated in a safe and swish neighbourhood-very upwardly mobile. You will not be disappointed by the neighbourhood. But this is a hotel with several problems. The front of the Hotel is undergoing major repairs and redecoration and is covered in scaffolding right now. Other maintenance work is ongoing. Hotel corridors are narrow and poorly ventilated. Another problem-there are only two elevators for an 11 storey hotel. The breakfast is perfectly satisfactory although the dining area could be much cleaner and the quality of service by the employees there is surly in the extreme. The rooms are standard and very functional-nothing special but if you are in NYC, you probably won't be spending too much time in your room. The level of housekeeping and cleaning was excellent. My only major complaint regarding the room was that the upper part of the pane of glass in the bathroom window was cracked and ready to shatter. I didn't dare open it. Would I stay there again? Yes, but only because of the location. Forgive the cliche but....this Hotel could be much better than it is.

My daughter is going to FIT next year, and we wanted to spend the night in the Chelsea area. The Comfort Inn Chelsea is in a great location, just off 5th Ave and Broadway, walking distance to Macy's, Times Square, and the Fifth Avenue stores. My daughter especially liked that the subway station was right there, and we were three stops from Soho (her favorite area!). The bedspreads appeared to be unwashed and somewhat stained. The room was tiny, and the bathroom was even tinier. The bathroom door was difficult to open as the bottom caught on the carpet. The air conditioner worked, though, and the beds (sans the icky bedspreads) were small but not uncomfortable. Breakfast was, well, included. My daughter told me to make sure I mention that the eggs were terrible. The front desk/concierge staff were quite nice. They have an exceptionally small lobby area, and I believe that they were refurbishing the exercise room area. The business area had two large computers, and free coffee was provided. I waited in the lobby for my daughter for more than an hour, and the staff were accomodating. The concierge kept our bags for the day while we went to the school. Overall, this hotel was clean, not uncomfortable, and adequate for our needs. The best thing about this hotel, to us, was its location!

This is a great place to start exploring NYC. Was in walking distance of bus lines and several subway stations. The suite we stayed in was small but the price was reasonable for 5 people for 4 nights. The bathroom didn't have adequate ventilation and smelled like wet towels after the first shower. Due to this, we requested maid service everyday. Did a great job cleaning, providing fresh towels, and making the beds. A continental breakfast was served from 7-10 am daily, but it's nothing to rave about. WiFi is available at adequate speed; it was slower than what I was use to, but I expected it. When I return to explore NYC again, I'd would come back to this hotel.

Clean and comfortable. Decent size room by NYC standards. Clean bathroom, comfortable beds and adequate work area with free WiFi. Self serve breakfast is included and was one of the better ones I have had with some fresh fruit and hot items. Good choice for reasonable price in NYC. I would go back the next time I am in that area.

If you are staying in NYC but are only using your hotel as a base to explore the city, then this place is perfect! It is cheap, clean and in a very good location.Otherwise, if you are here with a significant other or for a special occasion, i'd definitely stay elsewhere.

We stayed for one night recently. The staff was friendly and the room was small (as our most hotel rooms in New York) but comfortable. The beds were also fairly comfortable and we found the room to be pretty quiet. The morning breakfast was just okay, nothing special. As others have noted, they do charge $1 to store your bags and they make you carry it to the storage room yourself. You basically pay for them to unlock the door. The rates are okay for the city and the hotel is well situated near attractions, the subway, and descent eating.

I just stayed here last week, and it was great. The location could not be any better. 25th Street is very centrally located in Manhattan. You are a few steps from Broadway Street, and just beyond that is a great park that has a Shake Shack in the middle of it. Great food by the way. Also, the subway stop is on 23rd Street, which is only two blocks away. And if you know anything about Manhattan, you have to ride the subway. So, as you can see, location is amazing. As for the room, it was perfect. There were three of us, so we got two double beds. The room is rather small, but also rather big for a hotel room in New York. Beds were comfortable, there was enough space for three carry-on bags and a big checked bag on the floor. There was a flat screen TV, nice bathroom, and over all very clean. The real plus was the complementary breakfast. They had cereal, pastries, muffins, bagels, fruit, and fresh waffles every morning. And it went until 11 am, which is very nice if you were out late the night before. Also, alot of people complaine about the noises from the street at night keep them up. This place is on a very quite street, so you hear almost nothing. So, when you’re thinking about a hotel in Manhattan, remember that you’re most likely going to spend the least amount of time in that room, so you really only need the basics. This place has it all, and they do it very well. If I ever go back, I will stay here again.

We stayed at the Comfort Inn Chelsea for two nights this week for an AARP rate of $215 per night. The room we had was small and cramped, and the bathroom was minute. We arrived early in the day - around 11, and we told quite curtly that check in was not until 3, and that we needed to store our luggage. I was absolutely appalled that the "concierge" was charging $1 per bag for storage AND we had to carry our own bag there, and place it on the shelf. We left for a few hours and came back around 1pm, inquired about our room again, and again was told curtly by the front desk agent that check in was 3 pm - however, that there was 1 room available. Fine - we would take it, since we had appointments in the afternoon that we needed to get ready for. Upon retrieving our bag, again, the "concierge" would not get our bag for us - my husband had to do it. Hot water took a while to get to the shower, but the first morning was plentiful, the second morning, the water was tepid at best. Water pressure was okay. The condition of the room was questionable - distinct divets in the floor, that when you walked on it, you would literally sink about an inch into the floor, carpet was old and dirty, windows need to be cleaned. Needing to plug in my laptop to charge, the only available and accessible outlet was in the bathroom. We had to move the coffee maker to the bathroom just to use it. Housekeeping was questionable, as at 330 pm on our 2nd day, my husband called to inquire about housekeeping for our room, and was advised that "someone would be there between now and 6pm". No apologies from the front desk about the delay in service. Breakfast was okay - the usual bulk bakery items, microwave sausages, and instant scrambled eggs. We asked one of the concierges for directions to WTC from the hotel - and I was mortified that she didn't know the address of the hotel in which she works (had to look it up on her phone) - and again, charges $1 per bag storage - clearly this alone needs to be posted somewhere. When we checked out, not one question of "how was your stay?" or "Is there anything we can do to improve our hotel?" The desk clerk - same one who checked us in earlier - just didn't really seem concerned. Ugg... I would have rather spend an extra $50 per night to stay in a hotel that at least cared about me as a guest a bit more, and offered a bit more amenities.

The price and location of this hotel in NYC was very good. We were able to easily walk from Penn Station to the hotel. The front desk was very helpful and check in was easy. The rooms were small, but clean. The complementry breakfast was more than enough to start our day of sight seeing. I would recommend that you arrive early as the selection of food was a bit sparse towards the end of the morning. The only problem we encountered was the banging of doors when people entered and left their rooms in the late night and early morning hours. The hotel was in the process of remodeling so I am assuming the new doors and wall coverings will be a little more sound proof.

Our stay at the Comfort Inn Chelsea was great - the property has a convenient location just a couple blocks from two subway stations and Madison Square park. The front desk staff were courteous and efficient and even one of the maintenance staff we encountered on the way down in the elevator was super-friendly and asked us how our stay was going. The hallways are typical old Manhattan, narrow and littered with fire doors, but the room was updated, comfortable and quite large for the city. We were surprised with a dead-center view of the Empire state building as well - not too shabby! We were on the 6th floor facing the front of the building and while street noise was noticeable, this particular is not busy all hours of the night.Breakfast was typical Comfort inn fare, convenient and complimentary. All in all, a great value in a town not known for value. If you need to park, make sure you realize there is no on-site parking although street parking exists on the weekends and there are garages in the neighborhood.
user_name:
devm635csi
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I stayed here for one night with my husband and two children. I didn't mind the size of the room. We had two double beds plus a sitting area with a desk and a sofa. Also a refrigerator. Bathroom was tiny but everything was very clean in our room which was most important to me. Also plenty of hot water and good water pressure. Bed was comfortable and I never heard anyone in any rooms around us. Our door did rattle a lot through the night I think from when other people on our floor closed their doors. I just used the fan on the air conditioner to try an drown out noises and it helped. This hotel is less then a 15 minute walk from Penn Station. Also an easy walk to the Empire State building. The continental breakfast was typical; cereal, fruit, yogurt, pastry. The waffle maker is always a hit with my husband. We got there well before check in but we were able to store our bags for a $1 a bag. The only negative I noticed was the chairs in the dining area were very dirty and could use replacing or a thorough scrubbing. I definitely recommend this hotel for it's convenient location and clean rooms.

We stayed for a week in August 2011. It's tiny, the rooms are tiny, the location is great. The bathroom was smaller than bathrooms on cruise ships... come to think of it the room was smaller than cruise ship cabins. The breakfast is adequate & very tiny. Well... it's NYC, you get the picture. We had room 602 with 3 twin beds. The beds were hard than preferred, but not horrible. The staff was nice... oh and the elevators were (you guessed it) tiny. We had a AAA discount and for this area of Manhattan, including breakfast, this Comfort Inn was truly a good deal.

I stayed here on a school trip in april 2010. I stayed for a week here and the rooms were great. Their single bed was a double and there were great room facilities. The foods was not great here. You got a good continental breakfast in polystyrene dishes in a cramped area, but it is new York so there is plenty of places to go visit. So I would highly recommend this place

Four of us in NYC for the Holidays. Only place we could find with a 3 bed suite. Price is not bad, for NYC, the rooms are tiny though. Complementary breakfast is decent and the coffee is good. Would stay here again.

This is an smallish (maybe 10 stories), older hotel that appears to have been redone and rebranded as a Comfort Inn. We had a room on front of the building with a view of the top of Empire State building. Of course room was small, but clean and well stocked. We were shopping, eating and sightseeing hard all weekend, so didn't spend much time in the room. Perfect for our purposes. Got a good AAA rate for 1 king size bed during expensive holiday season ($242). Ate breakfast out - too many awesome options to waste time with cold cereal and a dry mini muffin. Really had no interaction with staff other than quick check in and checking baggage with concierge after check out while we did a little extra sightseeing before leaving town. But those were both pleasant. Subway is nearby and many lines stop at 23rd St. Eataly (italian market/food court/coffee bar) is close and a must stop, as is the Shake Shack in nearby Madison Square Park. We usually try to book a moderately priced hotel through applecorehotels.com (Hotel @ Times Square being our favorite of those) but they were all full and this hotel is similar and almost as good.

Just returned from a four night stay at the Comfort Inn Chelsea. Three mornings out of fourthere was no hot water, had to ask for towels as room service forgot to replace them when the room was cleaned.The room and reception needed a good dust as you could write your name on the dust that had settled. Out of the three reception staff only one was helpful, in fact the otherswere surly.

I've stayed here several times when all other hotels were full. It has some really nice rooms in the front of the hotel, and has some horrible rooms in the back and center of the air shaft rooms that feel and look like a prison cell, only darker. The free breakfast is packed most time so best to get there early to get a seat.
Fantastic view of Empire State Building from room 604. Clean, spacious room with very comfortable bed, fridge and coffee maker. Perfect for our first trip to New York!

After reading several reviews of this hotel I wasn't sure what to expect upon arrival. We was very pleasantly surprised when we got there. Although the room is small, especially the bathroom, it was well-decorated and clean. We had a king-sized bed which was very comfortable. We didn't have the best room in the house by any means. We had no view from the window except for another building directly across the courtyard. However, the hotel itself was well-maintained and had a lot of character. The original ceilings in the lobby had just been repainted and looked terrific. There was a small sitting area in the lobby with decent furniture. They were renovating the breakfast room to make it larger. Breakfast was the usual Comfort Inn fare. The hotel staff were friendly and helpful. The hotel itself is practically at the corner of 25th Street and Broadway. Only two minutes at most to the subway and the subway line took you either all the way up to Central Park or all the way down to the Battery without having to change trains. Very convenient. The hotel is only 5 minutes away from Macy's and the Empire State Building and a 15 minute walk at most to Times Square. All-in-all a very well-located, convenient place to stay in New York. There were a number of restaurants nearby. We ate at a place called Rogues on 6th Avenue which was reasonably priced and had good food. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a more reasonable place to stay in New York. Times Square hotels are so expensive! We paid $242 a night for 3 nights which isn't bad by NY standards.

We were placed in this hotel as booked a holiday inn hotel that was not ready for our arrival. This hotel is a great location for NYC. We arrived after a delayed flight etc, check in was simple and quick then up to our rooms (two couples travelling), we were on the sixth floor. No view from the window apart from other rooms but that didnt bother me as I wasnt planning on spending any time in the room apart from sleeping/changing etc. Room wasnt the biggest but enough room for two adults to be comfortable, was cleaned daily and was very clean. They also offered breakfast in the price which was good to grab something or even tea/coffee before heading out.Would stay here again for the price and location in new york.

We stayed here for 5 nights recently in the two room one bathroom suite(5 women). The rooms were small but clean and beds were quite comfortable.-view of Empire State building was a bonus. The room was quiet and we even saw a Serbian wedding in the church across the street. We could walk or take subway or taxi to anyplace we wanted to go. The breakfast was good and had lots of choices.

Had this hotel booked by our travel agents wholesaler after our original hotel had closed for renovation. Sadly this hotel was not up to the standard of other Comfort Inns I have stayed in. From the time I walked in I was unimpressed. We were on the top floor in a pokey little side room. We couldn't open the door fully as it hit the end of the bed. It was very noisy at night and also very hot, with an inadequate air conditioner. The breakfast room was like a college dorm room with paper plates and cups. There were 2 very slow elevators. One of them was so old you had to pull open a heavy manual door to step in. The front desk staff very not very helpful when we asked for directions to some of the most important buildings in New York. It was quite a walk to find descent restaurants open close by. All in all we did not enjoy our stay at this Comfort Inn and can only thank goodness it was only for 2 nights.
Small room, good location. OK for overnight stay in NYC during Fashion Week since all hotels jacked up their prices. Didn't have breakfast (included in rate) as the room was packed.

It's not the fanciest of hotels , rooms are quite small and the clientele appeared to be school tour groups.Front desk staff were professional and friendly but the location is perfect - located on uptown/downtown bus routes between 5th/6th avenues and well served by subway. The street itself is quite dark at night but overall in a great location for the budget minded traveller to NYC.
We went with 4 people and had 2 separate rooms. Simple but decent breakfast. Very nice location. Small but clean bathroom. 20 minute walk from Times square.

My husband & I were married in May (21st) & for his wedding gift I bought him Yankees tix & booked us weekender to NYC. I booked this hotel because of its location & good price. I didn't want to spend a lot for a room knowing we wouldn't be in it all that much. This hotel was PERFECT! Comfy beds, nice bathrooms, & a great view of the Empire State Building. There's free wi-fi, as well as a nice hot breakfast every morning & boy do they put our a good spread!! It's close to the subways (which is how we got around all weekend). The front desk told us to try the "shop behind the hotel" for food/beer. It was an amazing market (pic attached) that was a great tip. I'd definately return to this hotel when we return. It was a great value & very clean. Kinda small rooms, but thats expectated in big cities. Great Hotel!!

Unbelievably DisappointedI arrived at the hotel at around 3:00pm on July 28th. I was put off first of all by the make shift ramp right in the middle of the steps leading into the hotel. I understand the need to handicapped accessibility but this was a hazard to persons without a challenge to walk. Checked in without any problems, and was given room 705. I realized quickly that the hotel elevator(s) were slow and non-responsive and it was easier to take the steps, which I did. The elevator, when I did use it was more like a broom closet and hot! When I got off the elevator, I was met with a vacuum cleaner and a huge garbage bag full of trash. I litterally had to step over them and move the vacuum.I winded my way to Room 705 which was in the back of the hotel which was quiet, thankfully. Two double beds in a very small room and a regular bathroom. The trouble started when I tried to take a shower. NO HOT WATER. I was in a hurry to meet people for dinner, so hurriedly took a wash cloth but informed the front desk that the hot water did not work in my room. The woman at the front desk replied to my concern with “No one else has complained.”! Are you kidding me? I told them I couldn’t go with the maintenance person at that time, but would check with them when I returned. When I returned, I used my key card and it didn’t work, so down the steps I go to the front desk. They gave me a new key card and told me that my hot water problem was fixed. Back up to the room I go, start the shower, get ready and low and behold, NO HOT WATER. The only thing hot in that room was me!!!! I called the front desk and they sent some up, and long story short, I moved to another room directly next door. But this time, I knew I would only be staying one night. I checked out of the Comfort Inn Chelsea that next morning and went back to the W Hotel Union Square! This is what I get for trying to save a little bit of cash.If you don’t mind1) Slow and non-working elevators2) No hot water, or a chance of3) Rude check in and checkout people4) Your concerns not being met5) No wireless working (and you must pay when it does work) Then definitely stay at this hotel. The hotel itself is conveniently located on 25th Street right off of Broadway, and the N Q and R Uptown and downtown trains are a block or 2 away which is nice. This is probably the only thing that is going for this hotel.
user_name:
klocco1
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel is a good value. Also has a convenient location. Right near the subway and within walking distance of Penn Station. Our room was small and an odd shape (it was at the end of the hall), but it was also very quiet during our three night stay. There is an exercise room and continental breakfast (eggs, sausage, danish, cereal) is included every morning. The front desk staff was nice and helpful. They suggested we eat at the Shake Shack in Madison Square Park where the hamburgers are "the best in NYC" (and cheap too)! Met someone there who suggested Lombardi's Pizza on Spring St. for "the best pizza in NYC" (not cheap, but it was excellent). The concierge desk staff was also nice and helpful. I would stay here again!

I would not have been particularly pleased had I paid New York City prices for this room, rather than using points. The room itself was fine - small, but clean. There was also a free breakfast included, which looked OK. However, we did not take advantage of it since we were going to have our breakfast with our daughter who lives in Chelsea. Location was perfect for that, being only a few blocks from my daughter's apartment.  Location of hotel was also across the street from a small flea market (Sunday mornings?) and on the same street with some antique/flea market shops. It is convenient to Chelsea Market and High Line park. I was glad that our room was on the third floor because the elevator was either very slow - or, at times, not working at all. Finally, I was disappointed because I left my pjs hanging on the back of the bathroom door and when I called to inquire about them, nobody knew anything.

We just got home from our trip to NYC, and I had to write this review. This hotel was great!!!! Great price, clean, great staff, the view out our window was AMAZING!!!!!! Ask for a room on the front of the hotel. It is centrally located, and not more than a $15 taxi drive to about anywhere. The breakfast was way more than I expected. Fill up, and you don't need to eat again till dinner!!!! would I recommend it.....already have, and will again!!!! Would I stay again?? You betcha!!! Bottom line......great price.....small room, but not too small...great location......great staff.......don't hesitate....go for it!!! And many many thanks to Sherry!!!!

Stayed here for 4 nights with my husband and three teenagers. Was good value for money. Greta location and the breakfast was good. Would stay there again.Friendly helpful staff - My husband accidentally left a shirt in the wardrobe and they found it and put it aside for us.
user_name:
Michelle S
New Plymouth, New Zealand

review_body: We stayed at the Comfort Inn Chelsea for 2 nights in February. We were delayed arriving due to blizzards and I called from LA to let them know. There were absolutely no problems with our late arrival (midnight) and our room was ready. We had a family room which suited us and our teenagers perfectly. The location was great. Close to subways which we used to travel all around Manhattan. Breakfast is basic but fine for us. Got wrong directions from tour staff which was the only bad thing as it caused us to miss our flight. Delta rescheduled for us with no charge thank goodness. If you want good basic and safe accomodation for a family of 4, this is a good option.

My wife and I stayed here for one night in early June, 2011. I had been sent to NYC on a business trip, and my wife came along and we stayed an extra night on our own dime. We didn't want to spend $600 or more to spend another night at the New York Palace, so I searched for a low price alternative in a decent neighborhood.I guess you kinda get what you pay for sometimes. I've bargain hunted for hotels in NYC before and been happy with the results, but not so much this time. The hotel is small and everything about it is small. Tiny check in area, tiny (and slow) elevators and REALLY TINY rooms. We had a King room, and after the bed was put in it, there was room for little else. There's a TINY closet, a TINY bathroom with barely room for one person, a tiny desk and a small (but much appreciated) refrigerator...although it turned out the frig didn't cool very well. We left a couple of sodas in it, and after an entire afternoon and evening, they were barely coolish. The room is cooled by a window unit, which did a fair job on a super hot day...but was typically slightly noisy. We had no view (not surprising)...just the fire escape of the rundown building next door.I'm okay with a small room in a good location. We spent little time in the room. But this was the smallest we've ever had and it made everything was just a little run down too...so the whole thing just felt a little dirty and seedy. Yes, it has the Comfort Inn brand, but it didn't rise to even those normal levels of cheap but clean. The folks at the front desk were very friendly, and they actually had a tiny concierge desk with a nice young Eastern European lady working there. She helped us with a subway map, but we had no other chance to test her knowledge.The location was pretty good, though. It is on 25th street, near the corner of Broadway. If you walk to that corner and look south, two blocks away, view unimpeded, is the terrific Flatiron Building. Madison Square Park is also in site, so that was very nice. The park is lovely, and on this hot day, many New Yorkers were just laying on the grass soaking up the rays and letting their kids run around and have fun. Very nice. Just three or four buildings down from the hotel on 25th are several giant antique stores, including an intriguing antique mall that we spent a fair amount of time in. That was an unexpected treat. We strolled west down 23rd and passed lots of great restaurants, fun little shops and eventually arrived in the heart of Chelsea and the Hiliner park. It's about a 20 minute stroll each way from hotel to hiliner, but it's worth it. A less busy section of NYC,with some real architectural charm. Also, there is a subway station VERY near the hotel steps.SO, to be fair, the hotel was (relatively) cheap...and if money is a bigger worry than quality or cleanliness...you're probably okay here. I'd love to stay at this location of NYC again...just not at this hotel, I'm afraid.
great location with average looking rooms. good value for money. only criticism was the saggy bed. noise was not an issue although they provided ear plugs. would stay there again.

My two sisters and I spent two nights here in one of the 3-twin bed rooms on the 10th floor (#1002). The room had a front facing view of the church across the street and various buildings, but not of Empire State Building. The room was very small and dated, but was clean and the twin beds were comfortable. We didn't plan to spend much time in the room so we didn't mind it at all. There was street noise as well as the noise of opening/closing doors on our floor, but the hum of the A/C unit drowned it out a little. Registration and concierge employees were helpful. Free wifi was easy to use. We did not eat free breakfast here. Hotel is close to Flatiron Building and 23rd Street Subway station with easy access to Central Park, Times Square, Chinatown, Staten Island Ferry on the R Line. For the price and location, I would stay here again.

Stayed here alone last year. Was conveniently located for tourists, close to metro station and can walk to most attractions (even central park). Room was big enough for me, possible not had there been two people to the room. Clean, has a safe, free wi-fi connection. Breakfast was good, lots of variety, small dining area so can imagine it being busy in peak season. reception staff were very helpful and helped organise taxi journeys to airport and gave me maps etc. Street quite dark of a night, but wasn't a real issue. Has shops and restaurants located close by. Would stay here again.

I stayed at the Chelsea Comfort Inn for ten nights as part of a school trip, and was quite happily surprised at my surroundings, the hotel was clean and everything you would need in a hotel. I stayed in a room with five other girls and as you can imagine it became quite messy, nether the less the cleaners still made our beds every day and we had clean towels every day. Although being on the tenth floor i suggest you do not walk up the very narrow staircase, especially with suitcase like we had too!The breakfast had a varied choice although the breakfast area could get quite cramped and busy with no real system.I would recommend this hotel to anyone and really enjoyed my stay.

Front desk staff was pleasant and check-in was fast and simple. The hotel is a typical NYC hotel and the lobby was clean and seemed well maintained. Our room was exactly as the pictures on the hotel’s website portrayed and the rooms were clean. The hotel is close to a subway station and we felt safe walking to and from hotel (even at 2am).
Spent 1 day here, rooms are dirty, staff is rude, and beds have bed bugs. Don't stay here, you will regret it.

Stayed here for 5 nights in March and found the location excellent. Not too far away from the bus or train station for airport connections, and very central. The Flatiron building is just feet away and the Empire State building is well within walking distance. Time Square is just under 20 blocks away and only took about 15-20 minutes to walk. There are several subway stations very close by and these were very useful for getting around. Also several shops and restaurants. The bus stop for the 'hop-on hop-off' sightseeing buses is next to the Flatiron building so is within easy reach. The hotel itself is nothing special, room fairly small and the furnishings were quite outdated, but it had everything we needed. The staff were helpful, on one occasion our safe stopped working so we spoke to the front desk staff who arranged for it to be fixed within minutes. They also offered an airport transfer bus for $24 each, but we had already arranged to take the bus to Newark so didn't make use of this. The hotel was fairly quiet at night, except for a few slammed doors! No view from the room, but we didn't spend a huge amount of time inside it so this was no problem. It did offer free wi-fi which was a nice bonus!

Staff was extremely rude, the room was dimly lit. The linens were old and ragged.The "concierge" did not speak engligh, charged $1 per bag, cash only, then made me carry the bag down to the storage room.The breakfast selection was terrible, you had to beg for refills. I ended up leaving and eating elsewhere.The business center was a pay as you go internet connection. This one occassion, the hotel had 50+ teenagers running around slamming doors including the heavy fire door all night. I called the desk several times, no action was taken.

horrible hotel staff. treated me with a disgusting & demeaning attitude. THEY WILL NOT ONLY BE REPORTED TO CHOICE (and I'm elite diamond), but I WILL NEVER, EVER GO NEAR THIS HOTEL AGAIN. I left saying my stay was "just ok." I would rather report them to their franchise than deal with them as they clearly don't care about their guests. Ironically, their horrible way of manging this hotel and dealing with guests surely has got to hurt their business. Treating your guests with respect makes them want to return and spend more $$$$$$$$ duh!!! I cannot recommend this hotel based on my experience here. Their rooms are disgusting and have bed bugs.

Grandparents, parents and two boys aged 10 and 12 stayed here for 5 nights over the Xmas period, in a 'suite' - essentially 2 small connecting bedrooms (1 with QB and other 2 x DBs) with one bathroom. Very neat, clean but compact rooms. The heating was out of order but a reverse cycle aircon provided warmth (if a bit noisy!). Breakfast was included in the very reasonable price but was nothing special - loads of carbs on polystyrene. Staff were very friendly and helpful. Location was fantastic - very close to subway station. The one thing we found sad - not a Christmas decoration in sight! Not even a HINT that it was Xmas time - the main reason we visited NYC at this time of year. Oh well ... the city didn't disappoint!

The Comfort Inn is old on the inside but the room I stayed in was clean but very small. It served its purpose for my stay. The parking garage was not right next door but a short walk away. It was perfectly located for myself in wanting to explore more of the Chelsea/Greenwich Village area. There are no real frills to this hotel but it was clean, centrally located, and had a small but decent continental breakfast in the morning.
Room is clean, but rooms are very very small, no luxury. Breakfast is ok.

When I booked, I am not sure. Well, it is clean and nice surroundings. Room is clean. A lot of fun places nearby for you to go. If you want to have a drink, good places are available. I slept well. If you have someone to go with you, I think she or he will like this place too. And also new York city has a lot of places for you to visit. This is a nice place to sleep in. I did not use other stuff in this hotel or inn. But I am sure it is good though. Well, all in all, this was my trip, what you will have counts.

I travel on business all the time and my "regular" NYC hotel was sold out so I tried this one. Great location - can walk to restaurants and I felt very safe all the time. Courteous staff. In the morning, there were lots of European travelors at the breakfeast table and they were a bit crabby but overall, great place. I plan on staying there again.

We got the 1104 room, top floor, no buildings in front of us. Empire State view from the bed.The only issue is the sleep quality because of a group of young neigbours doing a party every night.Business center $1 / 5min.Good breakfast.

Well located in the center of NY, next to Madison Square Park, 5th Avenue, Broadway. Very near to a Bestbuy and Macy´s, Starbucks and other restaurants. CVS pharmacy on the corner of the street. On the week-end there is a flee market right in front of the hotel. Nearby antique shops are very good too. The staff speaks poor english (they are 90% indians - from India). The front desk clerks are helpful and educated. Shower is good and air-conditioning works just fine. They have TV and minibar (empty) in the rooms. Soda/water/ice machines are located in the lobby.Staff will not help with the luggage, not even for a good tip...

I spent 2 nights at the Comfort Inn with a friend. The good points: location, free breakfast, friendly staff, coffee in the room. Drawbacks: very small room with 2 single beds, desk (but you could not sit in the chair as there was no room to pull it out from under the desk), no where to sit outside the hotel (but I guess that's common in NYC) so when you're at the hotel you're stuck in this very small area. The windows were filthy. No view. Air conditioner was noisy. Very narrow hallways.

I booked in for 2 nights, but changed my plans and stayed an additional 5. The staff were very helpful and accommodating when i asked to extend my stay and even worked it out so i could stay in the same room. I stayed here alone but felt perfectly safe, the hotel is in a great location in the heart of midtown and the 23rd and 28th street subway stops are just a short walk away. The room was comfortable and clean, had an excellent shower and daily maid service. Coffee maker, fridge and good-sized safe were fantastic! A 24 hour pharmacy / convenience store is just around the corner. The area was relatively quiet, although a few nights there was a lot of noise from trucks in the street at around 1am, but it wasn't too bad. The elevator was a bit slow but you learn to love it. All-round excellent hotel which really enhanced my trip to New York.

Short two blocks to FIT. CVS drug store around the corner. Antique shops. Close to 23rd subway & 28th subway stops. 23rd has cross town bus service to Chelsea Piers and to Chelsea Market. The market closes at 8pm but there is abundant nightlife around Chelsea. I favor this area over TIme Square. The hotel is older and not fancy but a good deal for New York. On a quiet street. Free internet, breakfast & minifridge :)

My husband and I stayed at the Comfort Inn after reading past reviews. We were thrilled with the hotel. We stayed there for 5 days before heading off on a bus tour and re booked for a further 5 days at the end of the bus tour. The hotel is so central being an easy stroll to times square and all major tourist attractions. At the end of a busy day of sightseeing it is so relaxing to go over the road to Madison Gardens and take in the atmosphere of New York at its best. If we are ever fortunate enough to visit New York again we would certainly stay at the Comfort Inn.

The location of this hotel is fine and I guess the rates are good (for New York City), and although the actual room was clean enough, the windows were filthy and very depressing. The window air conditioner was very loud. I walked around the neighborhood the next morning and found the Radisson Martinique--more expensive, but a great hotel!

While it doesn't look like much from the exterior, the Comfort Inn Chelsea is a small, cozy and clean place to stay in a great area of New York City. I stayed on the top floor of the hotel, in a tiny room with a king-size bed and an amazing view of the Empire State Building. While the room was very small, it didn't feel cramped. The bed was very comfortable, and the bedclothes were just right. The bathroom was also tiny, but immaculate, and had the expected amenities -- shampoo, conditioner, little soaps, etc. The room also had a small fridge. The public spaces -- hallways, elevators, lobby -- were small and felt a bit outdated, but again, everything was clean. The room rate included a continental breakfast, which is served in a lounge-type room off the lobby. Breakfast offerings were the usual fare at such places: hardboiled eggs, bagels, waffles, cold cereals, coffee and tea, etc. The coffee was actually pretty good. Staff were friendly and responsive. When I reported that a smoke detector was beeping in the hallway outside my room, the staff changed the battery right away.The Comfort Inn Chelsea is a few blocks away from Fashion Ave., Union Square, Gramercy Park, and the Flatiron Building, and just off Madison Square Park. From this central location, you can walk to many of New York's most popular attractions.

Comfort Inn is in a great location, easy walking distance to Empire State Building, Rock Center, and Times Square. The rooms are very small but clean. No bell hop, just the housekeeping guy if he has time. Luis helped us with our bags. He is great! Very helpful and courteous. Service just OK. A very nice free breakfast buffet in the morning. If you are looking for great value and great location, I would recommend Comfort Inn.

We could not have picked a better place to stay on our weekend trip to NYC. I tend to scour the internet for the best room for the best price when making vacation plans. Almost every hotel in Manhattan charged over $200 (closer to $300-900) per night, and the ones that did not were either in questionable/inconvenient locations or involved shared bathrooms/accommodations. What's more, when I cross-referenced available hotels with reviews on various sites, the $300+/night hotels received complaints about bed bugs and dirtiness. (And I am not going to pay $300+ for bed bugs!) When I found the Comfort Inn Chelsea, I was sold--rooms for way under $200/night in a great location and CLEAN. (Note: if you're looking for a place with a spa, incense, fireplaces or floral arrangements in the rooms, this is not the place for you.) The rooms are standard, cozy (read: small by non-NY standards) but perfect if you just want a safe, comfortable home base while exploring the city. The bed was incredibly comfy (even comfier that those at a certain 4-star hotel in LA where you can buy their "signature" bed). The basic complimentary breakfast is just icing on the cake. The service at the front desk is attentive, friendly, and helpful. They even helped me with a random request to use their shredder (work-related). As for location, this hotel is in the Flatiron District (a few blocks from the Flatiron Building). Jay Z's 40-40 club is down the block and there is a beautiful church across the street. There was a weekend market in the church parking lot with antiques and vintage items to peruse through and a 24-hour CVS right down the block. You can walk or catch a quick cab ride to the Village, Soho, Midtown, Grand Central Station and/or Times Square. All in all a SOLID place to rest your head.

This hotel had a small triple room which was perfect from my extended family of 6. We had a 2 bedroom suite with 2 queen beds and a king and 2 bathrooms. The elevator was very slow and tiny! The price was unbelievable for the number of beds in our suite and the location. This hotel down a quiet street that seems a bit scary at night be we didn't have any problems. It is close to a couple subway stations which can take you anywhere in the city you want. If you do the "hop on hop off NY tours", there is a stop a half block away.

So for starters, if you're looking to stay on the island of Manhattan, there has to be a base understanding that real estate is at a premium here - whether it is with apartments, condos or hotel rooms. So to expect an extravagantly sized hotel room in Manhattan - especially at an affordable price - is an extremely tall and rather unrealistic order. That being said, I stayed at the Comfort Inn Chelsea recently with a friend. This hotel has a great location - right in the heart of Chelsea. Very walkable to many points of interest. It was an unexpected treat that there were several regular weekend flea markets that are held within walking distance of the hotel. I found it a plus that the hotel was located on a block of 25th St. that was not too noisy. Despite that, I felt safe walking around the hotel in the wee hours of the night / morning. Anyway, the building is old, strikes me as pre-war era but appears to be decently maintained. The lobby is rather small but the hotel makes up for that with their friendly staff. They have a business center on the 1st floor as well which offer internet access. Admittedly, the hotel rooms are on the smaller side. However, they were clean and well maintained. We were able to find a room with 2 beds for approximately $160 for a Saturday evening in NYC - a deal which is simply hard to beat in midtown Manhattan. The bathroom was pretty modern though the bedroom decor seemed to be a bit dated. They did not have a flat screen in the room, rather an older television set with cable. I do have to reiterate that these are all minor details compared to the fact that the room was CLEAN. Especially in a place like NYC where there is so much to see and so much to do, you'll likely just need a place where you can lay your head down at night.I would recommend this hotel to friends any day. I would definitely come back and stay here again.

I have stayed at this hotel on several occasions over the last year. In my case, I was doing business nearby and it was very convenient. The rooms are small but I have stayed in some other NYC rooms that were even smaller. They have all of the basics, TV, wireless (and wired) internet, comfortable beds, etc. It is a short walk to several subway stations that can get you anywhere in NYC. For those that like to walk, its not far to several attactions, but far enough that if you don't like to walk, you will need to learn the subway/bus routes. There is a good chinese restaurant that is adjacent and a number of other good restaurants within a few blocks, but I typically find myself several blocks away for dinner. For breakfast, they offer a typical continental breakfast with cereal, fruit, breads, juices, etc. There is only 1 ice machine and it is in the lobby. If you buy drinks and want ice to go with them, just ask the lobby staff for a bag on your way back to your room and they will give you one for your ice (so you don't need to go up to your room to get it).The hotel has 2 elevators, one of which is small, and can be busy in the morning, I have used the stairs but these are narrow and windy so best to plan extra time. The hotel is popular with international tourists in the Spring/Summer and can get quite busy.A few of the rooms offer a view of the Empire state room but most do not offer any view other than a fire escape and other buildings and a few face an internal courtyard.

I was surprised - for barely more than a hostel in the area ($130 with taxes), I was able to book an actual hotel room in an incredibly convenient location. I had a business school interview a few blocks away and needed a place that was close and not too pricey, and this fit the bill. The rooms are small, the elevator takes approximately ten minutes to arrive, and the amenities are minimal, but it was clean, quiet, cheap, and has free wireless if you bring your laptop. The bed was really comfortable and the room came equipped with an ironing board and iron. I would stay here again if I needed an affordable place to stay while visiting. The room would have been a bit cramped if there was more than one person, however.

This is not a hotel for a hotel-based getway, but we loved it to see New York City. We got a room with a King and ended up with a reasonable sized room for a great price. The room was clean, and with the exception of Saturday night it was quiet. The hallways were narrow, but not at all unexpected. We ended up with a great view from the front of the hotel with a view of the Empire State building. In addition it had a free wireless which was perfect for us. The location was nice, we were two blocks from W line, two blocks from the Sex Museum, and right near the Flatiron building. I would definetely recommend this hotel over a hotel near Times Square or other touristy areas.

I've stayed here three times for business and one time for pleasure. The rooms are small (but that's NYC), but comfortable and clean. This has been consistent with each trip. They offer free continental breakfast. It's a great location - walk to restaurants, bars, etc. in Chelsea and beyond. We ate at Mesa Grill one night which is an easy walk of about 10 minutes. On the first day we walked up to Central Park - for a frame of reference. A bit of hike but walkable if you don't mind walking and checking out the neighborhoods. A subway stop is only a couple blocks away. Overall, this is a great value. If this is your rookie trip to NYC, I suggest staying here for the value until you can get your bearings. But if you're not going to spend much time in your hotel, you'll probably end up booking here again like we did.

We stayed at the comfort inn for these last 11 days. We chose it because we read good reviews about it here. The reviews were right on- this hotel is a great value for money.The room was big enough and clean, the breakfast was sufficient ( doughnuts, bagels, cheese ....) the staff was pleasant and helpful and the location was great. A walking distance from the main sites in NY.We had a great time and we can't wait to go back to NY and to this hotel.

I visited New York with my sister and booked at this hotel because of its price and location. The really great surprise was its staff and service. My sister is disabled and so we needed a hotel that had a ramp for the hotel entrance. But prior to the trip she had taken a downturn so she also needed to be able to use a scooter in the room itself.
