We used the hanger in the room as much as possible and left everything else in the suitcase.At nighttime it was perfectly quiet so we were never disturbed by noise etc. Maybe the location of the room helped here.One funny thing: The main stairway had fire doors towards both hallways - made of wood!Location of the hotel is in Midtown. So almost everything is within walking distance or within easy reach with the subway.Compared to other offers in Manhattan, € 120,- p.N. seems reasonable money for value. You would get something more fancy in other cities but that's a different story...Btw, friends stayed at the Pennsylvania Hotel at the same time - their room and esp. bathroom was definetely worse than ours!

My first impression of the Arlington Hotel when I walked into the foyet was not too good. The foyet looked dirty and old fashioned and there were workmen coming in and out of the lifts.The staff were friendly enough though and then we made our way to our room. I had read reviews about the Arlington before I booked so I was expecting a cramped box room. But to my suprise it was a little bit bigger than I expected. There was a safe and a fridge in the room and the bathroom was almost brand new. Cleanliness, safety and peace & quiet were all I really wanted from my room\hotel and that is exactly what I got with The Arlington. (I discovered that the previously mentioned workmen were making improvements on the hotel - I must say that I was never disturbed by them once during my stay!)During my weeks stay I found the staff to be very friendly and helpful. The hotel was in a safe enough place with deli's, coffee houses, bars, a pharmacy, subway stations, shops (ladies mile) etc all within 2 mins walk.For those people who just want a hotel to come back to after a hards days shopping, site seeing etc The Arlington is ideal. Great location, neat and tidy clean rooms and friendly staff. I would definitely stay there again on my return to the Big Apple.

I stayed here for a December business convention.The hotel is in a good location near a couple subway lines. There's a nice club just steps away from the main entrance. Several 24hour deli's located nearby. Decent neighborhood.Hotel is not handicap accessible as it only has stairs at the main entrance. Once inside, there are elevators available.One of the first things I noticed going up to the room is that the emergency exit sign was just hanging by the cords. At least it was lit up :)The room was quite large by Manhattan standards but the carpet was quite dirty with bits and pieces of trash strewn about in both rooms. There was also noticable dust constantly floating around the room.The windows did not stop the freezing cold air, but the noisy radiator took care of that problem.Bathroom was quite clean and fresh towels were available. Bed had clean linens.Most of the handles on the dresser were missing or broken.*** Hints for future hotel guests ***1. Bring slippers, my feet were almost black after taking a shower and just walking around the room.2. Room smelled a little like cleaning fluid, so bring scented candles if you want.3. Bring earplugs for wintertime. The constant rattling and gurgling of the radiator would keep light sleepers up.4. Remind the front desk to keep the exit stairwell door clear of luggage carts. One night, I came down the stairs to find the cart blocking the door and had to reach around the door and slide the cart out of the way. This is one of two emergency exit routes.If I was to return and pay on my own, I'd probably look into staying here again since it is quite cost-effective :) However, I'd keep an eye out for slightly nicer accomodations.

Our stay at the Arlington was interesting. First time to New York so for the price we paid £220 for 3 nights we didn't expect the Ritz. What we did get was a great view of the Empire State Building from our room, clean towels daily, room service daily and a radiator that leaked scalding hot water which we were told was normal!!This hotel has all the basics you need for a stay in New York but is missing the touches that would have made it better such as coffee facilities in the room. The location is great whether you walk nearly everywhere as we did or want to get the tube.Maybe if you use this hotel ask for a renovated room as I assume they will be of a better standard.

stayed at the arlington over thanksgiving for 6 days, the hotel was okay not the best & certainly not the worst, was in a good location few blocks from empire state building 5 minutes walking distance & virtually around the corner is the yellow subway line which goes up and down manhatten, the hotel itself is having some renovation done but to no disruption to guests, the rooms are fairly big and kept clean, you have no wardrobe but a clothes rail on which you can hang your garments, beds were made everyday and towels replaced, only had one problem with not being able to turn down heating but this was soon resolved when maintenance was contacted. Personally this was a great base for my holiday as it was just used to basically sleep & shower the rest of the time was out shopping and sightseeing enjoying new york for what it is, i would recommend this hotel no luxuries just the necesseties. Enjoy your holiday !!UZMA :-)

During the 2005 New York city Marathon we stayed for 6 nights in the Arlington Hotel. We had a triple room on the 10th floor, with a view on the Empire State building. The bathroom was renovated, so it was new. The beds were okay. The only thing we missed was a cupboard. So we had to leave our cloths in our suitcases. The room was cleaned every day and also each day we got new towels. The hotel is perfect located very close to the subway and interesting places like the Empire State building. There are plenty restaurants in the area. Summarized this is a very convenient hotel which is worth to be booked.

We spent three nights at the Arlington with my wife. Reserved rooms trough Travelnow for 139+taxes and fees so three nites were 500 USD altogether. Although for this price everywhere else in the world you expect a super great room in NYC we were cautious and hoped only for a clean room to sleep in. IT was much better than we hoped for, our room 1001 was completely renovated with 30 some channel tv an okay sized room and an extremely clean and comfortable ...i would say downright perfect bathrooom. The bed was comfy, the towels were really thin but oh well. The staff unlike mentioned before were not all that bad. The girl and the younger guy and middle aged guy were very nice..only the older one was grumpy looking. Overall they were efficient and friendly enough. The view from our room as you see the picture was probably the worst one can wish for, but personally I prefer a cozy and clean place rather than a dirty with great view..because that is about the choice you have in New York except if you are willing to pay 500 and up a night. The Arlington is in a very good neighbourhood I would say 5 minutes to ES Building and two minutes to the Subway and Flatiron Building. In the neighbourhoods there are plenty of places for breakfast for under two dollars. If you are a power tourist you should get the new york pass and see as much as possible. Buy the weekly or daily metropass for 24 and 7 dollars they re well worth it if you plan to see a lot. The Arlington by the way is under construction and soon all the rooms will be nice, but for now I think only the top couple floors are in good condition. If you get good price I would definatly recommend to stay there. You wont be sorry.NYC is just magical.

On the Plus sideGreat location for a Hotel in Manhatten close to subway and on Orange and Yellow line on Broadway.Room was way larger than the average Manhatten HotelRoom was Spotless and Maid service was good even though they forgot to make the bed one day.Safe and fridge in the room were major bonused for us as overseas travellers with money and passport security a must.2 excellent breakfast / lunch diners on Brodway around the corner Irish pub on broadway again on 5th ?avenue around the corner.(very average pub but nice to get a night cap after slogging around NY)Very helpful concierge not sure of her name helped us with any questions we had. On the DownsideRoom on the 11 floor while quiet was was too hot to sleep with the air conditioning way too loud to sleep.Bed requested was a king actual size a double on wheels which was way too soft to be comfortable.Leaving luggage in storage be it for 2-3 hours cost us $1.50 per bag.Very tight.Hotel staff were indifferent and never seemed very welcoming or friendly.TV reception was poor and basic.Beware the first impression of th Hotel is very dirty BUT they are in the middle of renovations.If you access the Hotel from 6th Avenue the area does not look too friendly but from Broadway its OK.Generally OK hotel but I wouldn't recommend it for comfort andhospitality.

I have just returned from staying in the Arlington Hotel and I found it good for the price. The rooms are basic but reasonably clean and comfortable. The air conditioning was a very necessary plus and the mini-fridge and safe were also very useful extras. However i found the lifts extremely slow and you would probably be faster crawling up the stairs, so request a room on one the lower floors so that you could maybe take the stairs instead (we were on 9! not possible to use the stairs daily) Some other people that I knew that were staying there at the same time had a room to the front on the third floor, this proved extremely noisy on a saturday night as there is a nightclub a few doors up.It is in a reasonably safe area but I would recommend walking uptown on either 5th or 6th Ave instead of Broadway as we found a section of Broadway on the way to Times Square to be quite threatening. If you are looking for somewhere to put your head down after you shop/sightsee and you are on a budget and don't fancy sharing a bathroom then I highly recommend this hotel

This hotel is a wonderful value. If you want a gym, a spa, and a bell-boy to serve you dinner, then forget about it. This hotel was great! It had air-conditioning, a mini-fridge, and a safe to store your valuables. Ice is available downstairs. Room service comes in everyday and cleans. After reading other reviews, I only expected the worst, but really, I found the Arlington to be very nice.

Very basic hotel but very clean. Rooms have air conditioning, cleaned daily, with fridge and TV. On 25th Street and close to subway, great for those that don't intend spending time in hotel room, but why would you when your in New York? Would recommend to others on a budget.

I've spent 5 nights at this hotel - from 30th of July till 5th of August 2005. After reading reviews on that site I did expect a much worse place. But! Location is great!One block from Flatiron building, 7 minute walk to Empire State Building an 14 moinutes walk to Times square - actually I never used a subway or taxi since all the places of interest for me were easyly acessible by foot.Hotel itself looks worn out, with corridors requiring renovation, but rooms were clean, hot water was available, and a/c did a nice job during the very hot days in August. Towls are thin indeed, but there are four of them for twin room changed daily.Hotel is value for money, it's not that easy to find something on Manhatten in the price category.My only advise woould be - don't even attempt to use "high speed internet access" terminal in the lobby, since it buys you 5 mins for 1 dollar, but for the whole of these 5 mins you're just waiting for the system to load - and it hangs most of the time.In overall, I recommend this hotel for budget travellers, who are not expecting a 5 star treatment in 2 star hotel. But if you come there only to sleep - it's a good place to stay!

Me and my husband stayed in this hotel for 10 days. It's an ok hotel but don't expect ANY luxury. Very basic rooms, the bed was made every day and the room was clean (if you didn't look in the corners) The location is excellent, and very quiet. The staff on the contrary was very UNfriendly, but that didn't bother me. Cheap hotel, value for money.

I loved my stay At The Arlington It was great the rooms were cleaned every day beds where made with clean sheets the staff where very helpful aswell if you need information go to the desk i needed songs for my mp3 player and the staff directed me to my nearest internet cafe theres a brilliant view of the hotel from the top of the empire state building i thought it was fantastic that you could see the hotel from the empire state building

This place is perfect if you are visiting New York and don't want to pay extortionate (more than £100 a night!) prices.The front desk were helpful. They were opened when we arrived VERY late and arranged a private car to pick us up on our return journey VERY early in the morning.Our room was clean with fully funtional amenities, if a little old fashioned in decoration. The place probably needs a re-vamp, but this is par for the course in New York unless you stay at The Trump Plaza! Location is perfect. A 10 minute walk to Empire State Building/Times Square. I would advise using the Subway however. Buy a weekly ticket for about $17 gets real value as it costs you $1 per journey otherwise. The hotel certainly compares favourably to others, which, in fairness do look run down. Do not expect the Ritz, but an ideal base for a stay in New York. New York hotels are expensive. We paid about £80 per night and found this value for money in comparison to others which charge in excess of £100 for similar if not worse conditions.

I chose this hotel for my mother and I to stay at for our weekend visit to see a Broadway play. I used tripadvisor as a resource for making my decision to book this hotel. It was a good choice for us, as we had a limited budget to spend on lodging but wanted someplace clean and safe-feeling for rest periods and sleeping. We were very impressed. Rooms were cozy-small (fine with us), colors of bedspread, wall paint, curtains and carpet were modern and nice, and the bathroom (shower) was private. The room and the bathroom were very clean (we never saw one "critter" at all), and it was very quiet for being in the "Big City." Our view (10th floor) looked out on other buildings in the block, but we didn't mind. And, best of all, air conditioning during the early June 2005 high humidity!!!! We were only a couple of blocks from a great diner serving comfort food (on 23rd street), and half-block from Broadway and one of the stops for the Grayline double-decker tour bus. Budget-conscious travelers to NYC will enjoy this property.

(I actually used this hotel twice, in Sept 2000 and Mar 2002, so this review applies to both visits, unless indicated).Getting to your room involved either a miniscule, slow, crowded elevator, or climbing a claustrophobic stairway. (Most of the time I took the stairs, as doing so was much faster than waiting for the elevator).The room was tiny, but I kind of expected that to some extent. The view was of the adjacent building, but one doesn't go to a hotel like this for the view. TV reception (which seemed to be over the air, not cable?) was fuzzy.The phone required a deposit, even for local calls (and they were expensive). My cell phone didn't work inside the building, so I had to step outside each time I needed to make a call.The bathroom was ok, if a bit musty. However, in 2002, I noticed some flaking wall material near the radiator. This was unnerving, as visions of asbestos danced in my head....In 2000, there was a little breakfast room, and upon check-in, customers were given vouchers good for breakfast. After one breakfast dealing with low-quality food and snotty staff, I decided to have my breakfast elsewhere. This facility had closed entirely when I went back in 2002; I don't know if they've ever reopened it. (There's a adjacent Chinese restaraunt that may be associated with this hotel, but I didn't try it).The immediate neighborhood is fine, (on 25th between 5th and 6th Aves) is fine, but somewhat dim after dark. You're not too far away from busier streets (and 24-hour delis) though....The subway is just a block south, and plenty of buses and cabs ply 5th and 6th ave. The hotel will also call a car service for you, if you need to get to the airports.All in all, probably not the worst place, but you can probably do better, with careful searching of the travel sites, discussion groups, and, of course, Tripadvisor!

March 10th -17th. After booking my holiday to stay at the Carter Hotel, a few weeks later the travel agent advised me to change to the Arlington because of all the bad reports, and after seeing the Hotel Carter in the flesh, I am grateful. This was my first time in New York. I went over by myself to fulfil an ambition of mine - to visit this fantastic city.I couldn't believe the location of the hotel, it was great, right beside the junction of 5th & Broadway and next to the Flat Iron Building. I enjoy antiques and got a further surprise, when I found that the street was full of antique shops and home to a flea market at the weekend, where I got some great bargains. The street does look a bit rough, but I never had a problem with anyone. The hotel has good facilities for its price. My room was clean, and kept clean every day by the cleaners. It had a shower with hot water, a large comfortable bed and a TV with about 20 stations. I know we don't go on holiday to watch TV but its good if you don't want to be out at night. The room also had an electronic safe. The view from the window was a brick wall, I laughed when I looked out and thought it was quite novel after seeing so many movies featuring the city. It's all part of the experience. In the reception, there are vendors, phones and a computer offering internet access, which was great for communicating with people back home. The staff were very helpful and friendly - I bought a phone card at the Empire State and couldn't get it to work right, asked the receptionist at Arlington for help and she phoned the number and put me through free of charge. The card wasn't working because I forgot to skip the "0" at the start of the area code, there's a handy tip! There is also a Chinese restaurant on the ground floor, I never ate there, so can't tell you what the food's like. Just around the corner is a small grocery shop which offers a good selection of hot and cold snacks. I usually went there in the morning for breakfast on the move and then on to McDonalds, Burger King and loads of sandwich bars at night. There is a nice restaurant at the Rockefeller centre, but if you want to eat there, remember and pack for the dress code.I never took a taxi or the subway anywhere except to and from the airport. I just liked to walk from place to place and take in as much of the city as possible. Add to that, they drive like maniacs, practically every car has a dent! The hotel is only a short walk from the Empire State Building, which offers stunning views of the city and is close to many points of interest. Overall, I thought the hotel was great. The decor was out of date but who cares? Your here to admire and enjoy the city, not the confines of your hotel. It it does the job especially for someone like me on a budget. I can't understand all the negative comments other people have made. The staff were friendly, the room comfortable and clean, great location and cheap - What more do you want? If you have the money, then spend it on a better hotel rather than be a stooge. You get what you pay for. If -no- WHEN I go back to New York, I'll be staying here again for sure!The attached photo is a view from the top of the Empire State looking towards downtown Manhattan. I have pinpointed where the hotel is. You can see hotel from the ESB. The hotel is just in front and to the left of the green church roof.

Not a good value---actually a DANK dismal, depressing place on a block which matches it. I paid $119 for one nite--never again. The late nite and a.m. Front desk staff (dressed very casually) were polite, but my stay was brief. I can see why another reviewer could not get a customer satisfaction survey. The owner should hide under his desk in a fetal position rather than take the likely bad feedback.MY REVIEW: Where do I start? OK--SLEAZE bag decor, narrow, ugly corridors and multiple twists and fire doors to get to your equally ugly room (Bathroom was clean with hot water). Entire place looks unkept. TV is basic, few stations, poor reception--no cable noted. Locks poor--I put a chair against the door. Carpets look like old indoor-outdoor style. THE WORST PART? My window looked out on HELL--a clump of filthy rags hanging on barbed-wire, backed by a brick wall of filthy windows in the adjoining building's window. The front desk acted like this was a surprise to them. UGH. There are far toooo many hotels in NYC to go this route. The Milford, for instance, may have small rooms, but the overall experience isTONS better and the neighborhood superior.

May 2-5. After reading the previous posts here about the Arlington Hotel, I wasn’t sure what to expect. Upon arrival I laughed to myself as I, like the other reviewers, immediately noticed the slight smell of cigarette smoke and general mustiness. My first impression of the room was “kinda dumpy”, but after awhile, the place began to grow on me.The room was clean as was the bathroom. No bugs or critters of any kind to be found. The shower pressure was great and plenty of hot water. Yeah, the towels were thin, but they gave us as many as we wanted. There was a safe in the room as well as a fridge, TV, phone, AC and dresser. (if you want a pen – bring one! No pens/paper in room) Vending machines were in the lobby (drink, snack, internet, ATM) No ice machine on premises. That would have been nice.We were on the inside side with the closed-in breezeway. At first I was bummed that we had no view, but soon realized that it was much quieter than the streetside in the city that truly never sleeps. My biggest complaint was the size of the beds. I was there with a friend and we had 2 twin beds, which are about 5’10” long. I am 6’3, my friend, 6’5.The location is great… Only 2 blocks (about a 2 minute walk) to the subways. Call the hotel directly for room rates before booking with an internet site. Their rack rate was $10/night cheaper than I paid on hotels.com. All in all, if you are looking for a clean place without any hassles, this property was well worth the $.

The Arlington Hotel is priced right for the budget traveler - - - but when I return to New York City, I will probably spend a little more money for a slightly nicer hotel. The Arlington is suffering from neglect - - - and was in need a some cleaning, plus the bed was not comfortable (old lumpy mattress) - the shower head was missing, and so was the knob on the air conditioner. The staff was pleasant enough. I recommend it as an acceptable budget hotel in a safe and convenient neighborhood - but don't expect too many creature comforts.

come on give the hotel a break,if you want a classy hotel with room service,bell boys,and fancy dinners and some one to wipe your bottom go some where else,its new york why do you want to spend time in the hotel anyway.i found it just what i needed a place to crash for four nights and in a good area as well quite central to everywhere and i thought the staff were great they said hello and good morning what you wanting an invite for dinner.if you don't want much for the the money you paid try it out i thought it were greeeeaaatttt.new york is amazing and it was my first time there by the way have a great time you will love it.

We have just returned from 5 wonderful days in New York and having booked a quad room last September at the Arlington we were very pleased to find our budget accomodation was warm, clean had very comfy beds and was in the best location for sight seeing. No its not very appealing to look at but as you are out all day and just need some where to sleep its absolutely ideal.

The Arlington is actually a perfectly sound budget hotel which I would be happy to recommend to anyone looking for budget accomodation in NYC. What you have to be prepared to accept is the inevitable shortcomings of budget accomodation. This was our first trip to NYC from the UK. Upon arrival the exterior of the hotel is uninspiring, although the reception staff were courteous and polite throughout. Probably the most distressing time was the initial journey to the room. Hallways and corridors ARE rather tired and shabby and even the rooms appear low rent at first sight. What we soon relaised was that this WAS budget accomodation, but that important things were there. The rooms were clean and serviced daily, there was a safe in the room, and the staff were friendly. I would certainly stay there again

Just got back from NY and found this hotel to be ideal for what we wanted. Due to the fact we were only looking for a room with a bathroom this was ideal. I agree with an earlier post in that the corridors did smell odd but was more then happy with our room which was clean and perfect for our stay. Good location for sightseeing giving you oppurtunity to easily reach downtown or the Times Square areas easily by foot or Subway. An absolute must when visiting NY is a visit to Cafe Wha (bar/club) on Macdougall Street, Greenwich on a wednesday or Sunday when the resident band play who are amazing.

On our first trip to New York City in September 2004, we stayed at the Arlington Hotel.Compared with other hotel rates in the city, the Arlington seemed much less expensive and so we were not expecting the height of luxury. However, we were pleasantly surprised by the standard of accomodation. The room was basic, but kept very clean; en-suite bathroom with shower, TV, safe, telephone, desk, air conditioning and comfortable beds. The staff were friendly and in the lobby area there are some vending machines, a small shop selling postcards, etc, a telephone and internet access. There is also a small Chinese take-away restaurant accessible from the hotel lobby with 3 or 4 tables that you can sit at if you are looking for a cheap meal before heading out for the night.Located close to the Flatiron building, almost at the junction of Broadway and 5th Avenue, the Arlington is in a wonderful central spot of Manhatten - a few minutes from the Empire State building and there are plenty of pubs, clubs, shops and restaurants within easy walking distance.I would definately stay there again and highly recommend it to those who want a comfortable (but not luxury) place to sleep - if you ever feel you want to sleep when there is so much happening in New York City!

Booked this hotel in September 2004 for a weekend trip in February 2005. Made it clear that we wanted a TWIN room (just me and my 15 year old son going). When we arrived, no twin room available. I wasn't impressed, especially as I'd booked so far in advance AND already paid. Eventually we were offered a fold-up bed. To be fair, they brought it up to our room straight away. The room was at the back of the hotel so fairly quiet. The hotel in general could do with some love and attention but it's clean. We had to ask for extra blankets as the room was very cold, but we weren't in it for long. At least the shower was hot! Good location although for the money I'd rather go to the Newton (stayed there last year) 2528 Broadway.

We visited this hotel from 21st feb-27feb 2005. As soon as we checked in we encountered a problem. The man behind reception obviously had better things to be doing, than doing his job. He was rude and couln't wait to get rid of us. We got into our room and found the same problem as, Boston Dec 2004 did, the room was so hot, we had all windows open at all times. However the room was clean and tidy. When we travel we like to do our own thing, however some things arose where we asked the staff for some help, ie airport transfers which we paid 52 dollars for. We booked the time of the transfer with the staff behind reception for 4.30PM to go to the airport. At 4.30 am we were woken from our sleep, and being rudely asked why we were not downstairs! An honest mistake, maybe??? Our receipt stated that we were to be picked up at PM. The problem was how badly we were treated. We later went downstairs to confirm that our booking was still confirmed for the afternoon, again this was to much of an effort for the staff and again were treated badly by the staff. I would like to say that it was only one staff member that was rude, however they were ALL rude, unprofessional, and unwilling to help us.Overall, we had a clean room in a hotel with a good location. However if you would like to be treated with respect DO NOT GO TO THIS HOTEL!!!!!!

If you ever get the chance to go to NYC DO NOT stay in the Arlington Hotel . We stayed there unfortunately as we had been appointed by a travel agents and did not have much choice. The reception is filthy and has a chinese restaraunt attached which is basically a 'down and out' drop in centre!! The rooms are smelly dingy and the bedding had hairs in it. I was forced to buy my own bedding and pillows as I couldn't bring myself to sleep on the hotels sheets. We stayed for 3 nights and eventually checked out as the final straw were mice running around in the ceiling!!!!!!!!!!! Our room door was tried for entry one night and because we were in we didn't get robbed but we basically felt vulnerable and unsafe at all times in this Hotel. The smell on the corridor was so bad( like body odour) that we had to spray air freshner so that it did not seep into our room. We have travelled to New York on numerous occassions and have never stayed in such a dump in our lives. Whatever you do do not inflict a stay at the Arlington on yourself you will truly regret it!!!!!!

Absolutely no complaints about this hotel and would definitely stay there again. For the price you pay you'd be a fool to expect a spacious, pristinely decorated room with top of the range gadgets.It's clean (maid service daily), it's warm, there's plenty of hot water and the staff are competent and accommodating. Then there's the location: Less than 15 minute walk to the Empire State Building and a very pleasant 30 minute walk to Times Square.If money is an issue then this is the hotel for you. If it isn't then enjoy your limo to the luxury 5 star hotel of your choice!!

After reading some of the negative reviews, i was prepared for the worst, however was pleasantly surprised. We would recommend room 603 if you are a party of 3-4 people. The room was split into two seperate rooms. one with a double bed and twins in the other. The room ,bedding and bathroom was clean. There is a fridge, safe and tv in the room.We had a View of the main street which looked a bit shady, however if you look up towards the sky, you get a great view of the Empire state building. The heating was on the brink a couple of times and when it was reported, the staff didn`t come up and fix it. It seemed to resolve it self for some reason. The club 40/40 is along the street but we didn`t hear excessive noise. In the hall on our floor there was a stench of mold and urine but we just thought it was funny as we had read other previous reviews about this. The room certainly didn`t smell of this. The staff do charge to keep your luggage but it is a small charge of $1.50 and it is kept in a safe place. I honestly cannot fault this hotel. It is every thing what i would expect from a budget hotel in NY. It is a no frills hotel where you are safe in your room at night with a clean bed and a hot shower. What more do you need when your out all day. Would use this hotel again:)

Easy and cooperative staff, very reasonable price, and was given a single w/ extra bedroom and private bathroom. Very important to me! Overall, surprisingly good. Location- easy access, neat architecture. Id go again if I can't splurge on a"fancy" hotel.

Hotel is ok for the money. The rooms were bearable seeing as you don't have to spend long in them. Carpets were dirty but sheets on bed clean and clean towels. Good location and there is the 40/40 nightclub next door which is great. No view but not that bothard about one.Bit annoyed that on the last night we reported the heating wasn't working and nothing was done about it. Spent the last night absolutley freezing which was a bit bad seeing as it was so cold outside.All in all if you just want to make it as cheap as poss i would recommend here. Thought it was a bit cheeky that the hotel makes you pay a fee to store your bags in a room after you have checked out

Decided to book a room here after reading lots of your reviews. Was not disappointed at all. We had a great room on the 6th floor facing the Empire State Building during the week after Christmas and including New Year's Eve at a price that was insanely low, especially compared to what many other so-called budget hotels were charging. A lot of people, in their reviews, complained about the noise from Club 40/40 next door, but even with our window open, it wasn't loud enough to bother us. The desk people were always helpful when asked anything. Yes, the rooms are on the small side, the bathroom is tiny, the towels are skimpy, and the hallways narrow, but who cares? We didn't come to NYC to spend our time in the hotel, and the shower was hot, the room was clean (w/a frig in it even), the heater worked great and everything was functional. Also, the room was cute; with art deco sconces on the wall and the room painted a bright apricot. The location was fantastic! We walked everywhere from shopping in Soho to back from Times Square on New Year's Eve (a long walk), and we'd definitely stay here again!

We stayed at the arlington just before christmas and found it to be just what we expected for the price, cheap and cheerful! Most importantly though it was clean and although the decor was slightly dated I would recommend this simply for the excellent location, right near the flat iron building and a five minute walk from macey's. We would definitely stay here again, unless we won the lottery of course, and use our money for what new york is most famous for, shopping !

My boyfriend and I went to this hotel 2 years ago in July. The rooms are normal size, the carpet was a bit dirty, so were the walls. We didn't have a view, but then we didn't ask... I can't say the bathroom was dirty, it seemed clean but when the decoration of a room is updated, it always looks dirty and that was the case...Anyway, the staff was quite nice, the hotel seemed popular with european students, there were germans teens running all over the place !!! Also the hotel is very well located, near flatiron building and that is a good point. So if you're on a budget, this hotel may be good for you, but make sure you know it's not a 3 star one...

Stayed at the Arlington 12/13/04. Even at a budget hotel, I expect a clean room. It was a bit musty, and the hallway of the 5th floor had a distinct tinge of urine and ashtray smells. The room itself was just barely OK with an almost comfortable bed, lousy pillows, and a steam pipe that gave off so much heat that even in winter, with all the windows open, it was still unbearably hot and dry. Unfortunately, we were in a pinch and got referred to this hotel by another hotel that displaced us, so we had no real choice in the matter. Tiny rooms, tiny bed, scratchy linens and useless towels. The water pressure was akin to be urinated on by a Chihuahua. Just generally a bit skanky, but pretty much what we expected upon walking through the door.

My girlfriend and I stayed in a double room here for four nights in December 2004.We were initially apprehensive due to the cheesy neon HOTEL sign outside as we approached along 25th street, complete with dodgy letter 'O'! The lobby, lift and hallway are all fairly skanky, with a dodgy smell in the corridor. So we weren't looking forward to entering the room, however it was fine.There was a clean comfortable bed, adequate lighting, a TV, fridge, safe, tables and mirror. The bathroom is small but the shower is hot, and not unappealing to use. Although I maybe wouldn't want to have a bath!Our room also had a chest of drawers and a walk-in wardrobe. All quite usable.Window had ugly view out to fire escapes etc, but there are big thick curtains which you can keep closed.The radiator makes a bizarre hissing sound when you switch it on, this is quite unnerving. But it's ok really.Towels were replaced every day, and the bed was made up with fresh sheets. It was nice and quiet in the evenings, and is in a safe area. It's a stone's throw from the Flatiron building so nice and central, about 10 minutes walk from Penn station, and handy for buses and subway.Carpets are rather old and the room really could use a lick of paint. Oh, and the door rattled a bit whenever the fire doors in the corridor were opened/closed.But it's safe, clean and comfortable and that's what matters. At around $150/night, this is excellent value for a capital city (especially for us lucky UK tourists with ultra low $/£ prices right now). If price matters to you then this is a very good base from which to explore the big apple.

This was our first time in New York. I realize that finding a good hotel at a fair price is impossible but for $155/night I expected better. The room and bathroom were clean although the furnishing were Spartan at best. The lobby and hallway were dirty and smell of urine. The staff was not helpful at all (always on the phone). We could have overlooked all these things but could not overlook the nightclub below which spewed out music well in the night. After the club closed (4am) the patrons decided to bring the party outside so we were entertained until 5:30am by the sounds of rap music, car alarms, horns and people, in various stages of inebriation, practically screaming. If you value a good night sleep after an exhausting day of sightseeing and shopping avoid this place.

I really don't like to leave negative feedbacks, but that is due!The reservation was made by a friend of mine so i had not the chance to check the Hotel b4 booking.Shame on me.Fact is the hotel is real cheap and is poor too! We spent there 2 nights: the first one i couldn't get any sleep cos a heating pipe made a terrible noise all nite long: i asked the front desk to change room and they did: they gave us another room (#405, noisy one was 406) on the road, quite noisy but not for the heating pipe.Clean? Forget it. Beds and linens itched, bathrooms were ugly. Won't stay there another time. If you really would like to experience a good one, see my review of the Second House on Second Ave, whose daily rate for the Modern Suite is 155 $... quite the same price we paid for a double room at the Arlington. Needless to say the staf at Arlington were not so helpful: i asked them about the little flea market across the street (it is held EVERY GIVEN SUNDAY) and they told me nothing, just shrugged and said "don't know nuthin"... They charge you for 1-800 calls (if i recall correctly it's 1,09 $) and they also charge you for every piece of luggage you leave at the facility when you ahve a late flight (1,50 each). A chinese take away is on basement floor though i have to say, no fancy smell came thru the Hotel.I know you don't go in NYC to stay within an hotel rooms, but still i wouldn't stay there again. The aisles on the 4th floor were quite smelly, though no coackroaches were to be seen.

Stayed 23rd Nov - 30th found hotel to be excellent value for money. Rooms cleaned every day with clean towels (although a bit thin on quality) changed daily. Great position just around corner from Flatiron building and 10 mins walk Empire State, Macy's and Times Square. Staff were friendly and helpful. Did not use chinese next door but this was by preference. Would stay here again next time in New York.

We picked this hotel from reviews on this website. We did our homework and didn't expect much more than a place to sleep and shower. We were not disappointed in the least. Staff was more than helpful and kind. If you are budget minded...this is your hotel. We are 4 females and never felt unsafe in the area or the hotel. Kudos to staff member Patricia for all her help.

We stayed at the Arlington for 3 nights during july. The room was clean and the beds were comfortably. The bathroom although small was very clean, the shower worked well and was always hot. We had a room at the back so it was very quite although the veiw out of the window was of a fire esacpe. The staff were helpful, we twice had a problem with our safe and both times it was sorted out straight away. This hotel is in a good location and the subway is only two blocks away. If your in new york to see the sights and not to sit in your hotel room then for the price this hotel is excellent, i would stay here again.

We booked at the Arlington for 5 nights after reading reviews on Trip Advisor. I would recommend the Arlington for budget-minded travellers, but there are some things to be aware of. First, make sure you book a room with a private bathroom - we had one, but were around the corner from the shared bathroom and the smell was quite something! Our room was small and there were virtually no amenities (not even Kleenex!), but it was clean and the bed was comfortable. For me, this was the most important consideration. However, there is a nightclub a couple of doors down from the hotel, and while it wasn't a problem during the week, on Friday and Saturday night, the noise kept us up most of the night (till after 4:00). On the upside, it's a great central location, right near Gramercy, walkable to Washington Square Park and the Village, Madison Square Park is right there, and there are some very good restaurants in nearby Gramercy. Just watch out for that nightclub...

just back from a weekend at the Arlington and agree with the others reviewers - it is basic and clean and it's selling point is it's fabulous location between 5th and 6th avenues on west 25th street. It's right by 23rd street subway station and there are good bus routes on 5th ave (for downtown) and 6th ave (for uptotwn). less than 10 blocks away is the Empire State Building. A room at the back of the hotel is quieter and there is plenty of hot water for showers. As other posters have pointed out, you don't gop to NYC to spend your days in a hotel...A word of warning: don't go to the Rogue Bar on 6th Avenue and 24th -it's a rip-off - over 7$ for a glass of wine and 7$ for a beer - you can do better!

We stayed in the Arlington for a week at the beginning of October and we had an excellent time. The hotel is just off Broadway in midtown - really convenient for seeing all the sights in that area. Alternatively, if you want to travel downtown or uptown, you are less than 5 minutes walk away from 3 different subway lines, which makes it really easy to get around. The inside of the hotel is a bit shabby - they could definitely do some work updating and improving the reception area - but the staff are very friendly and helpful.Our room was quite dark but there was good lighting in the bathroom (very important for us girls when we're getting ready to go out!) It was amazingly quiet at night and the bed was comfortable. It was also a good size with ample storage space, including a safe and a fridge, which was very useful.We were out for most of the time during the day and when we came back it was great to find the room cleaned and fresh towels put out (albeit sometimes a little bit worn).If you are planning a busy holiday in New York and you aren't planning to spend too much time in the hotel then I would definitely recommend the Arlington. Everything you need is provided, it's very central and it's cheap!

I am used to staying at the wyndam hotel every where else i go, so i was a little afraid of what we would be getting. It is a budget hotel, but the staff was so helpful when we needed directions. They would map it out and even gave us maps. They stored our luggage when we first got there because it was before check in. The rooms were very clean, in fact we got upgraded from a double room to a triple room! We had no problems whatsoever. It is also in a great location to go see things and close to the subway!! I highly reccomend this hotel if you are looking for a hotel with a good price!!

I stayd at the Arlington hotel last week of July. I booked based on recommendations seen onthis site an the price $115. both the lobby and rooms were rather worn and basic but for the money in NYC cant expect much else. The two lifts are old and very slow. I had a double room on 10th floor and would echo the comments made about the back roms not getting much light but being quiet. Hot water was plentiful and air conditioning worked though was rather noisy.Hotel is only a few blocks walk from the nearest subway station so handy for getting out towards the sights and nightlife. Overall hotel matched expectations - and provided you go in with eyes open I would recommend the Arlington for those who want to keep their money to spend in the shops or bars etc

We stayed at the Arlington Hotel on 25th St. Let me tell you we were pleasantly surprised. We arrived and expected some crummy little room, since we could not afford something more luxurious, but we got a big room with all the necessary comforts. We were on a budget while in New York, and the Arlington was perfect. Great location, very comfortable, quiet, great price and most importantly very clean. We had a great stay there and will definately go back. My stay there definately makes me want to go back real soon, we had some good times at the Arlington in fabulous New York City.

if your looking for a luxurious hotel in nyc then dont go to the arlington but when visiting new york who wants to stay in their hotel room ? if you are looking for clean but affordable this hotel is for you. The room was clean with a safe and t.v the bathroom was spotless daily room service was good aswell . good location too just a short walk to times square but just as easy to head downtown aswell. I travelled to nyc in august and most hotel prices were very expensive but the arlington was very reasonable .

I stayed at this hotel on the basis of the positive reviews on this site. I was rather disappointed--the rooms are certainly clean, if a bit worn and stained, my main beef is about the bed linen and towels which were so old that they were getting very thin in places. The room I had was also very dark even in the middle of the day.

After reading some terrifying reviews of low budget hotels in New York, I was still unsure of what a hotel costing only slight more would behold, thankfully the Arlington was nothing of the sort. The staff were friendly and quickly got us checked in. The triple room I had with my brothers was clean and came with a mini fridge, free use of the room safe, large tv, good air conditioning unit and a decent power shower, oh and three single beds! (phew, no fights over which two have to share the double) The location just off Broadway couldn't have been more central (just a mile from Time Square and across from the Flat Iron building.) The room was cleaned every day with the beds made and towels changed. Ok, it's rough around the edges with chipped paint work and the lift is the last word in speed but it's excellent value for money, secure and in a good, safe, central location to get out and about in Manhattan. I'd happily use them again.

Just got back from a 4 night stay at this very hotel and i must say i was very pleased with my choice! I shared a room with my two brothers and we were expecting perhaps one double bed and a sofa/fold out bed but no, we had three single beds! What a bonus! Not something you really see in any hotels but it really gave us all 4 good night sleeps.The bathroom was small, but perfectly fine. The shower was great, really powerfull and hot at all times. The room was cleaned everyday and we got fresh towels and soap. Plus there is a free safe in the room which was a great surprise.As for other reviews saying that the area was a bit rough, i didnt really see any evidence of that. We had a couple of late nights and didnt feel uneasy making our way back to the area. Hope this review helps! If your looking for clean, functional and in a great location the Arlington is for you.

I like this hotel! Good bargain, great location (near three subway lines) and very comfortable. Room was a decent size, very clean and there were plenty of hangers for your clothes (small detail but means lots to me). If you're looking for a good economy hotel, nothing fancy in a great location, book this hotel.

This is a nice hotel in all..the staff was nice...but the nieghborhood was bad...me and my friend were scared to stay out past 9.,.the rooms were nice and neat...the only other problem is everyone said it has the perfect location near everything...i went there and i felt we were out in the bonies we had a nice walk to even go anywhere...over all its a nice hotel...and i recommned to stay there if u like to walk

I booked the Arlington last minute and used the reviews here to decide what would be a good hotel for a low price and I was not dissappointed. I stayed in a twin room from july 7th to july 21st. Location: The hotel is in a great location, at the corner of 5th and Broadway. The Flatiron building is round the corner, the Empire State Building is less than a ten minute walk away as is Penn station, Madison Square garden and lots of shopping. There are some great bars nearby too such as the Flatiron lounge (really good cocktails and a great atmosphere). Theres also a Subway around the corner that brings you to times square, central park and downtown. Plus a 24 hour deli at the end of the block for food. On saturday and sunday there's a huge antique market across the road from the hotel. Hotel: We asked for a twin room and got room 911. A little worrying but everything was fine. The beds were comfy, the room was clean, the tv, fridge and safe worked, we couldn't hear noise from any other room and there was always hot water no matter when we showered. We were at the rear facing a an internal courtyard so didn't get much light, but there was no noise from the street. The aircon was in the window and a bit rattly sometimes but i never woke up with a sore throat that aircon causes usually so i'm not complaining. The staff were great and the lady on reception was really friendly and helpful. There's a place to store your luggage on the last day and arranging a shuttle to the airport was easy. There's an internet kiosk in the lobby (which has amazing ceiling plasterwork) but it's a bit expensive. We mainly used the easyeverything in times square. All in all, i was really happy with the hotel, it's great value for what you get. Don't go expecting a five star luxury place and you won't be dissappointed, it's easily as nice as some 3star places i've stayed and i'll definitaly stay there again. And a quick tip, there's 2 elevators not just one, the second one is opposite the gift store and no-one seemed to use it but us when we were there.

Room is small, but it has everything that a two stars hotel would have. Bed is small, for a 5'11", my feet was hanging out at the edge of the bed. I went with relatives and friends. I must said the size of the rooms varies. #1110 was smaller than #307 and #307 was smaller than #301. In all three rooms, none was suited with two beds (as displayed on expedia) I guess we were expecting to see two beds per room, but were disappointed when arrived. BUT location is a plus!! If you just need a place to sleep at night and goes out during the day, this is a good bargain (as many have mentioned, you get your own bath in your own room, thus one of our room has a very tiny bathroom).Club 40/40 is just few hundred feet away from the hotel. We even saw a Maybach and a Bently parked near the hotel :)Hotel staffs were very nice and friendly.If they can improve one thing, that would be get a bigger and more comfortable bed. I wasn't able to get a good night sleep the first two nights.

We stayed there on may 2004. You get what you expect for the price. I've to admit that I was a little worried about cheap hotels in new york. We chose these one because it was the only hotel for that price that did not have bad reviews (bugs!), and because it had safe box at the room, and fridge. The room was very clean when we got there, but I'm not sure that the maid cleaned during our stay. But the sheets were changed every day!. The bathroom was o.k. too, but very tiny towels. We asked for more and there was no problem. Remeber to ask at the front desk if you have any message, because they dont tell you if you dont ask. But people there is kind.Three subway stations near. Excelent location, quiet nightborhood. I think that for the price, it is the best option. I will stay there if I go to NYC again!

The hotel room was excellant. The room was large enough, clean, comfortable and the bathroom was lovely. Basically if you just want somewhere nice to sleep this was perfect and for the price, superb. The tv was big and the fridge, airconditioning and safe were in working order. All the rooms are similar so there are no risks and the maids do a good job daily. The only thing to watch at this hotel is the reception. It is small and inefficient and there were some messages that we did not receive, do not rely on them. I had a brilliant time in New York and it will not disapoint. Remember that the cars dont stop for you to cross theroad and tax is added on after pricing. Otherwise have a good trip, you will not be disapointed if you stay here.

We (I and three others) stayed at Arlington hotel one week in May 2004. Just like the subject says, you really get value for every dollar you pay: 149 $ (including taxes) for 4, you really can't beat that, right?LOCATION: Great location, walking distance from many interesting locations (E.g. Flatiron building, ESB, Union square and charming Madison square park) and near metro stations. We used metro a lot, and found it fast, safe and the network was extensive. Even though we like to walk in the cities, it is wise to travel fast to the location you are interested in with metro and then walk as long as you like and then take metro back to your hotel.RECEPTION: We arrived quite late to the hotel, and the receptionist was very friendly and helpful (behind the bullet proof glass, but I understand that it is more or less common in New York). Later on the other employees we saw were not that friendly, but every time we needed or asked something we were served seemly (at least in Finnish standards).ELEVATOR AND CORRIDORS: Elevator was ok, and pretty spacious also, corridors not so inspiring, but hey, who spends more time in corridors than is needed? Anyway, after the narrow passage to our room, we were just a little afraid what waited us behind the door.ROOM: However, our frights were not met, and the room was clean, pretty spacious and decently decorated. I wouldn't recommend eating from the floors, but if you do that in any place, maybe you should try and seek help anyway :) We had two bedroom junior-suite, but I think the only reason it was called suite was because it had two rooms. The beds were pretty firm, even hard you might say, but every morning I said to my wife that they were actually quite good to sleep in. The view was not to be called anything but the wall for the next building, but it also meant that there were no street noise at all. Air-conditioning was basic "window-installed" box, working and useful even in May (outside temperatures were from 20 - 30 degrees Celcius). TV with maybe 20 channels, and a refrigerator which was not working when we arrived, but was fixed immediately when we asked for it.BATHROOM: Ok, next to the bathroom, decent with shower and bath. I didn't try the bath, but shower worked fine, considering the two faucet system they still use in the US, it takes five minutes to adjust the water temperature right (that's because the system not the hotel). Enough hot water for all four of us. Towels were quite small, though they were changed regularly and were clean. Overall, the bathroom was not luxurious by any standards, but either we weren't fright to use it when needed to.MISCELLANEOUS: No breakfast included, but no problem to find good diners and delis nearby. Good selection of brochures, "what to do" leaflets and maps in the lobby. If you have a spesific question about the hotel or NY, I will gladly help if I can. Sadly one week is not enough in NY, but now we know what to do next time. Have a very nice stay in NY! We surely did.

I went to New York 2 times from Taiwan in 2003. My trip was lovely. First time went alone, second time with my brother. Staying at Arlington Hotel make my trip more enjoyable, all because of the "LOCATION" & "LOCATION" again, have own bathroom, safe and refridge even a plus plus. Especially at the end of a day...you would know, what so important about the location...by the way, QVB supermarket just around the corner and Starbucks Coffee...Fuel of my seoul...next time to New York....Arlington again...

I choose the Arlington solely from the reviews on this site on my first trip ever to the US. I have gathered from other reviews that not every hotel in NY is clean and cheap, which was something I wanted very much. And it was! The room was nothing to write home about but it was clean and it must have been the quietest room in New York. It was facing the back, a very small backyard - almost like a shaft, and you could barely make out what the weather was like as the shaft was that narrow and we stayed on the fourth floor. But we slept like babies, even though the pillows were like concrete.But since it was quiet, clean and with a great location (just steps away from Broadway and Fifth Avenue) and for that price (we paid $90 for a double) - I would definitely recommend the Arlington.

We went to the Arlington Hotel in December 2003 before Xmas. We bokoed it a week before our arrival and communication via telephone and fax was very clear. The street its on was a bit grotty but it was so central and easy to find.We had a family room as they had no double rooms, and we got a lot for our money for 5 nights! The room was spotless. Beds clean, bathroom clean etc. We took our own towels, as we took advise from another post here, but it was not that necessary, they were fine. I had heard alot about bed bugs and cockroaches but none of this here. I was very happy.My only gripe is, next time I will ask to be at the back of the hotel. We were at the front. NYC is 24 hrs so the clubbers and the dustbin men would wake us up. However saying that some nights we rolled in in the early hours and other nights we slept like babies as all that walking tires you! Plus we had the view of the Empire State building!Overall I would stay there again.

Just got back from the Big Apple and stayed at the Arlington and it is a superb budget hotel. Spacious room with a double bed and TV. Clean sheets and bath towels changed daily. The location is ideal, a 5 minute walk to the empire state building and one block from the subway. Within a stones throw from the magnificent flat iron building, and the Met Life Building is across the road too. Good value and location for money.

Stayed at the Arlington from Feb. 7-9, 2004.Start with a caveat. If you want an awesome hotel, with a spa and a doorman and that looks after your every whim. Look elsewhere. The Arlington is for the person on a budget that wants good value for money.My two nights at the Arlington cost $85 each, which is a great price for a double bed and a private bathroom and really great maid service in mid-town Manhattan. No complaints about the bed - it was nice and firm. No complaints about smells, bugs, or poor furniture. The place was nice and clean and smelled fresh.The location is almost perfect. Within a longish walk to central park and a longish walk to the tip of Manhattan. If you're in good shape, you can walk to almost all of the major sites in New York without ever taking a taxi or a subway. The neighbourhood that the hotel is in itself is nothing to write home about, but it's a five minute subway ride to the Village, Soho, Chinatown... well, basically every cool neighbourhood in town.The place isn't perfect - no onsite parking, no tub, slightly worn look to the walls and carpets, ever so slightly dodgy street (nothing I'd worry about, though), slight wait for hot water, and thin walls. These deficiencies are more than made up for with the price, solid value, and fabulous location.

We stayed at the Arlington Hotel, 21st Nov - 26th Nov 2003. We had read the reviews previously and booked the hotel on the basis that the rooms were clean. We were not disappointed as the room was vey clean including the bathroom which had a very nice power shower in it. Our room was in the back of the hotel so we had no view whatsoever but as the 40/40 nightclub is only a couple of doors away we didn't get the noise from that filtering through. One great item we were impressed with was the FREE OF CHARGE safety deposit box in the room, which gave us piece of mind to leave our passports and valuables in while we explored the great city. That is what we came to NY for, to explore, so we only used the room for sleeping, washing and a place to store our stuff. At £75 per night for the room (including taxes) it was money well spent and I shall seriously consider staying at this hotel again when I return to NY in the hopefully not too distant future. PS. I'd heard stories of cockroaches in New York, so I'm glad to report that not one was sighted here. PPS. The 'TEL' on the neon sign has been repaired while we were staying there so the sign does now read 'HOTEL' and not 'HO'.

At $120/night in mid November, this is no bargain. Sure the pictures look alright, but the room distantly resembles the picture. The street entrance is not very appealing, but the neighborhood itself isn't bad. Though I could hear people yelling from next door's 40/40 night club in the early morning hours. The "HO" as both sides of the neon sign indicate, is located across the street from a church and about a half block from downtown and maybe 2 blocks from the nearest subway entrance. It's a good location, walking distance to everything a traveler could use (CVS Pharmacy is about 1/4 block away and Starbucks is right around the corner).One of the first things I noticed when I got into the room was that not as big as the picture presents it to be. The bed is about 2 feet away from the desk and minifridge and close to the walls on the other sides. The beds are firm and bouncy, the pillows like slivers of padding, though one of the pillows was fluffier than the other. The blankets are terrible, like a cheap polyester blanket that has barely survived hundreds of washes in the laundry machine. Otherwise the room appears to have a pretty recent coat of orangish textured paint, but is well lit despite the reflected light from the walls.Lets move onto the bathroom. First thing you'll notice when you walk in is that it's hot as an inside of a black car basting under the hot sun. Opening the small 1'x 2.5' window helps a little, but because of the 3" diameter hot water pipe that runs veritcally from floor through to the ceiling along one wall, you can never really cool the room. But maybe because of that pipe, the shower was hot most of the time and water pressure was good in our room. The tub/shower is like a mushroom farm with the curtain closed. The curtain is a heavy baby blue plastic that blocks out all light, while you can leave one end of the shower curtain open, it tends to splash water about. One last thing, I'd suggest bringing your own towels because the one's they provide are thinner than the rags I use to dry parts of my car. They also don't provide hand or face towels, just bath towels sized for a 4 foot tall child. The towels are clean though.Positives: - Friendly and helpful staff - someone always at front desk 24 hours a day, maid does a very good job organizing room and bathroom - restocked every morning with new bars of soap and mouthwash - free minifridge and safe (together about the size of a nightstand) - clean sheets (I didn't have a blacklight on hand to really check) - great location - free HBO - no visible cockroaches or rodents - chinese restaurant, atm, internet access in lobby - internet access available in rooms for $0.50/minNegatives: - no face or hand towels, bath towels very thin and not very absorbent - bathroom is hot, kids could get burned on the pipe - expensive for what we paid - rooms are crampedYou might get a better room rate by calling the hotel direct then going through one of the internet referral sites.

A great hotel if you are in New York on a budget. I presume that anyone who is in New York is only sleeping in the hotel room if not what exactly are you doing. Ideal location ten minute walk from macys and fifteen minute walk from Times Square. Felt very safe walking to and from hotel. Staff very helpfull and airport transfer $45.00 in a limo. you can also see the Empire State from the steps of the hotel and you are one block from the Flatiron building. Room cleaned daily, fridge, safe, TV and air con. Would use this hotel again.

Nor are you sharing the apartment with any six-legged brown critters.If you've never been to New York City, you have to understand that what you get here for $100/night is not necessarily the same as what you'd get in Hootersville. And it's not necessarily what you would get at another big city. "Budget" hotels in NYC can average around $150 a night, and you still might be sharing a bathroom with another guest. Anything under $100 is probably a refurbished crack house.The Arlington isn't posh by any standard, but you get a clean, roach-free room, a private bathroom, a safe, a small fridge, a TV, and A/C. You can also get Internet access for 25 cents a minute. The walls are a bit thin...this may be a problem if your neighbors are keeping odd hours (it was for us). Location was good...midtown Manhattan in the Antique District, walking distance from two subway lines. And you have a nice view of the top of the Empire state building at night.All things considered, it was a relatively good bargain for us at about $125 a night.
Rooms are spacious and clean. Subway-Stations are close. Its hard to beat the price of less than 100$ per night. If you travel on a budget the Arlington is a geat choice.

It is not The Mark, but it is a clean spacious room in the center of Manhattan. The staff is great and you get a clean room with a full bath for under $100. Not a single roach, that is nearly unheard of. It seems mostly European and Asian occupied, so it has a great international feel. Quiet and Central. Highly recommend for the budget traveler. My room with two beds, desk, cable TV, refrigerator and safe was $85 a night in March.
